documentation.title: Outstanding debt for deceased relative how to stop the bills coming?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: My uncle passed away a few years ago, and owed quite a bit of money, I believe he owed on the house and perhaps on a loan. He did not leave any money in his will, and we ended up paying for his burial. Somehow the collection agencies got my mom's address and are sending her all sorts of bills. Obviously we are not responsible for the money he owed, but how do we get them to stop sending them? It's stressing her out. 

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: In the US, when a person has unpaid debts and dies, those debts are to be paid from any assets of the estate (as in, *any* assets). The executor has the responsibility to use those assets to pay the debts. Presumably the executor did that, and there are no co\-signed accounts or anything like that, so your mother isn't responsible for these debts in some obscure way. The [Fair Debt Collection Practices Act](http://bankruptcy.findlaw.com/debt-relief/the-fair-debt-collection-practices-act.html) has a provision that you can tell a collection agency to stop communicating with you, and they must then stop communicating with you except to say they are stopping attempts to collect, to indicate possible remedies (i.e. lawsuits), or notify of an actual remedy (they have actually filed suit). Since they are no longer allowed to discuss anything with you once you give them the go\-away notice, one should probably hire an attorney to exercise the nuclear option. 
You can also request proof that you owe the money: they are suppose to notify you of the right to dispute the debt with 5 days of first contact, which gives you 30 days to dispute the debt. Persuading a debt collector that they are pursuing the wrong person is probably easier than persuading a jury in a lawsuit.

0.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: When a person dies with unpaid debts, which of the following statements is NOT correct according to US law and the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act (FDCPA)?

A) The executor of the estate is responsible for using the deceased's assets to pay off any debts.
B) Family members are automatically responsible for paying the deceased's debts if the estate cannot cover them.
C) Debt collectors must stop communicating with you if you send them a written request to do so, except for specific circumstances.
D) You have the right to request proof of the debt within 30 days of the debt collector's first contact.

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: 
A is correct: The executor does have the responsibility to use the deceased's assets to pay off debts.
B is incorrect: Family members are not automatically responsible for the deceased's debts unless they co-signed on the debt or are otherwise legally responsible.
C is correct: Under the FDCPA, debt collectors must cease communication upon written request, with limited exceptions.
D is correct: The FDCPA gives you the right to dispute the debt within 30 days of the first contact from the debt collector.

The correct answer is B because it's a common misconception that family members automatically inherit the debts of their deceased relatives. In reality, debts are paid from the estate, and if the estate cannot cover the debts, the creditors generally must write off the remaining balance unless there are specific circumstances making others responsible (like co-signing).

documentation.title: Can an extra-terrestrial be legally adopted?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: ***Background:*** My [client](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Superman) has disclosed to me that he is an extra\-terrestrial entity who arrived from another planet some time after 1900\. He was sent to Earth in a rocket by his (now dead) parents, then placed up for adoption and legally adopted by two US citizens from the state of Kansas.

We are trying to determine whether this adoption was legally valid, specifically **whether there is anything in US Citizenship law, US Adoption law (or US law in general) that states that a "person" or "citizen" specifically needs to be human.**

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: There is longstanding and well\-established legal non\-uniformity in defining ‘person’, and in stating laws in terms of ‘persons’. The [RICO statutes](https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/18/1961) (18 USC 1961 (3\)) states that a person ‘includes any individual or entity capable of holding a legal or beneficial interest in property’. A corporation is a person for the purposes of access to the federal courts, for purposes of forming contracts, and enjoyment of First and Fourth Amendment rights, but not for purposes of voting or 5th Amendment immunity. [1 USC 8(a)](https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/1/8) states that 

> the words “person”, “human being”, “child”, and “individual”, shall
>  include every infant member of the species homo sapiens who is born
>  alive at any stage of development

which states a sufficient condition, but not a necessary one.

In Washington state, [RCW 1\.16\.080](http://app.leg.wa.gov/rcw/default.aspx?cite=1.16.080) says that 

> The term “person” may be construed to include the United States, this
>  state, or any state or territory, or any public or private corporation
>  or limited liability company, as well as an individual.

Washington does not define ‘individual’, but we can call on Black’s Law Dictionary to learn that

> this term denotes a single person as distinguished from a group or
>  class, and also, very commonly, a private or natural person as
>  distinguished from a partnership, corporation, or association; but it
>  is said that this restrictive signification is not necessarily
>  inherent in the word, and that it may, in proper cases, include
>  artificial persons.

And finally, Roe v. Wade 410 U.S. 113, 157 holds that an unborn instance of *homo sapiens* is not a person for purposes of the Fourteenth Amendment. In short, there is no clear and settled answer to the question.

Courts do not always refuse to hear ground\-breaking cases, and in case this issue is ever realized, I am confident that cert. will be granted. The point of law is, after all, to state general principles regarding what is forbidden or allowed in a society, thus it must be capable of addressing novel situations. We will have to await that case, but the prospects for your client are good. It is obvious that “persons” have a special position under the law, it is recognised that they have both rights and responsibilities that other things do not have. Summarizing over millenia of jurisprudential thinking, we can see that the special status of persons (when not reduced to divine gift: not applicable under current US law) derives from the fact that persons have a capacity to reason, and to choose actions based on their reasoning. In the context of our current knowledge, this is mostly coextensive with being an instance of *homo sapiens*, though in case of severe or complete limitation of those faculties, an instance of *homo sapiens* may not be legally accorded the full set of rights and responsibilities of *homo sapiens*.

In fact, the law does not have a definition of *homo sapiens*. Before objecting that science teaches us that only earthlings can be *homo sapiens*, we should be remember that courts do not always hold that terms as defined in a scientific discipline are to be interpreted that way under the law, which is how SCOTUS in [Nix v. Hedden 149 U.S. 304](https://supreme.justia.com/cases/federal/us/149/304/case.html) was able to hold that a tomato is not a legal fruit. The plain meaning of *homo sapiens* is completely consistent with extending legal coverage to Kryptonians.

Thus it will be the finding of the court that petitioner, not a member of the species *homo sapiens* but endowed with the faculty of reason and free will, has all of the rights and responsibilities of a ‘person’ under Kansas law, and has the right to be adopted.

1.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given documentation:

Question: According to the information provided, which of the following statements is most accurate regarding the legal definition of "person" in the United States?

A) The term "person" is uniformly defined across all US laws and always excludes non-human entities.

B) US law explicitly states that only members of the species Homo sapiens can be considered "persons" for legal purposes.

C) The legal definition of "person" varies depending on the specific law and context, and may include non-human entities in some cases.

D) The Supreme Court has definitively ruled that extraterrestrial beings cannot be considered "persons" under any circumstances in US law.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The correct answer is C. The documentation provides several examples showing that the legal definition of "person" is not uniform across US laws and can vary depending on context. For instance:

1. RICO statutes define a person as including "any individual or entity capable of holding a legal or beneficial interest in property."
2. Corporations are considered persons for some legal purposes (e.g., contracts, certain Constitutional rights) but not for others (e.g., voting rights).
3. State laws, like in Washington, may include various entities (including corporations and the government) in the definition of "person."
4. The definition can change based on the specific legal context, as seen in cases like Roe v. Wade regarding unborn humans.

The document also suggests that the law might be flexible enough to potentially include non-human entities (like extraterrestrials) if they possess reasoning capabilities, although this has not been tested in court.

Options A, B, and D are incorrect because they suggest a uniformity or restrictiveness in the definition of "person" that is not supported by the provided information.

documentation.title: Does the arrivecan app go against the Canadian charter?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: I was looking through the Canadian charter, and [Section 6](https://web.archive.org/web/20220904075741/https://www.canada.ca/en/canadian-heritage/services/how-rights-protected/guide-canadian-charter-rights-freedoms.html#a2d) piqued my interest. It states, in subsection 2, that

> Every citizen of Canada and every person who has the status of a permanent resident of Canada has the right to pursue the gaining of a livelihood in any province.

Doesn't the arrivecan app (and subsequent forceful quarantine, and/or fine) infringe upon this right? Directly after the above subsection, it goes on to say, in subsection 3:

> The rights specified in subsection (2\) are subject to any laws or practices of general application in force in a province other than those that discriminate among persons primarily on the basis of province of present or previous residence

This to me seems to say that only provincial laws can override the aformentioned freedom. Since the arrivecan app is federally run, doesn't this mean that it is not legal?

It seems that the government only chooses to follow Section 6 subsection 1 of the charter

> Every citizen of Canada has the right to enter, remain in and leave Canada.

by allowing the citizen to still enter if they refuse to use the arrivecan app; however, from what I understand, they breech it by forcing a quarantine and/or fine for not using it.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: It is generally understood that governments **do** have the right to quarantine citizens in case of epidemic outbreaks. In nations with a rule of law, the extent of quarantine regulations may be challenged in court.

A challenge against the app [has been filed](https://torontosun.com/news/national/group-files-constitutional-challenge-of-arrivecan-app-in-federal-court), and trying to second\-guess the court by reading sections of the constitution seems to be pointless.

2.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given information:

Question: According to the information provided, which of the following statements best describes the legal status of the ArriveCAN app and related quarantine measures in Canada?

A) The ArriveCAN app and quarantine measures are clearly unconstitutional because they violate Section 6 of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms.

B) The ArriveCAN app and quarantine measures are definitely legal because the government has unlimited power during health emergencies.

C) The legality of the ArriveCAN app and quarantine measures is uncertain and subject to potential court challenges based on their interpretation of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms.

D) Provincial governments have the sole authority to implement and enforce quarantine measures, making the federal ArriveCAN app illegal.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The correct answer is C because the legality of the ArriveCAN app and related quarantine measures is not definitively settled. While there are arguments that these measures might infringe on rights outlined in Section 6 of the Canadian Charter, it's also generally accepted that governments have some authority to implement quarantine measures during epidemics. The issue is complex and open to interpretation, which is why a legal challenge has been filed in federal court. The ultimate determination of the app's legality will likely depend on how the court interprets the Charter rights in the context of public health measures. Options A and B are too absolute in their claims, while D incorrectly suggests that only provincial governments have authority over quarantine measures.

documentation.title: Will using CC by-sa content in a book prevent me from holding copyright?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: I've been reading up a little bit on the CC by\-sa license, because I found a really helpful Stack Exchange answer that I would like to use in a book that I am selling. This answer is really short (only about 30 words long), but I modified it a little bit. With that being said, if it only takes up a very small portion of my book, and is not the main idea of my book, would I still be able to sell it and prevent redistribution (not using the CC by\-sa license)? I am fine with allowing redistribution of my paraphrase of the answer, which will only be a paragraph long in the entire book. The most similar question I could find is [If I use CC\-BY\-SA image in a video, must the whole video be CC\-BY\-SA?](https://law.stackexchange.com/questions/41267/if-i-use-cc-by-sa-image-in-a-video-must-the-whole-video-be-cc-by-sa), but that question is for unmodified content. Is a footnote with attribution (direct link to the answer) enough? Should I contact the person who wrote the answer? Thanks so much for the answers :D

edit, just realised how much I used "answer" in that paragraph, sorry

edit 2, would I be able to license only a section of my book under CC by\-sa, and then provide attribution like so?[![enter image description here](https://i.stack.imgur.com/Ic4sz.png)](https://i.stack.imgur.com/Ic4sz.png)

(source of this attribution: [Creative Commons wiki](https://wiki.creativecommons.org/wiki/Best_practices_for_attribution)

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: One cannot use a post **relying** on the CC\-BY\-SA license, without complying with the SA part, that is unless the entire work in which it is incorporated is released under the CC\-BY\-SA license.

In the absence of license permission, a would\-be reuser is in the same position as if the source work had been published with "all rights reserved" that is with no permissions granted to anyone except to read it. The source work might be quoted
in such a way that it falls under fair use in the US, or a similar exception to copyright in other countries. Proper attribution will help the case for fair use. Or the source work might be rewritten suffici8ently that its use is not an infringement. Or one might ask the original author for specific permission, outside the CC license, which the author might choose to grant.

3.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: An author wants to use a short (30-word) Stack Exchange answer in a book they're selling. The author has modified the answer slightly. Under what circumstances can the author use this content without making their entire book subject to the CC BY-SA license?

A) The author can freely use the modified answer without any restrictions as long as they provide proper attribution in a footnote.

B) The author must release their entire book under the CC BY-SA license if they use any part of the Stack Exchange answer.

C) The author can use the content if they license only the specific section containing the modified answer under CC BY-SA and provide proper attribution.

D) The author can use the content if it qualifies as fair use, if they sufficiently rewrite it to avoid infringement, or if they obtain specific permission from the original author.

Correct Answer: D

Explanation: The correct answer is D. According to the documentation, using content under the CC BY-SA license requires complying with the Share-Alike (SA) part, which would mean releasing the entire work under the same license. However, the author has three potential options that don't require this:

1. If the use qualifies as fair use (which may be helped by proper attribution).
2. If they rewrite the content sufficiently so that it's no longer considered an infringement of the original.
3. If they obtain specific permission from the original author outside of the CC license.

Options A and C are incorrect because they don't comply with the Share-Alike requirement of the CC BY-SA license. Option B is incorrect because it's not always necessary to release the entire book under CC BY-SA if there are other ways to use the content legally.

documentation.title: Facebook blocked my account until I consent to their new privacy policy under GDPR. If I consent now, will I be able to withdraw my consent later?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: I am going to delete my Facebook account in a month, I can't do it now because I still use it for work. I live in the EU and Facebook has blocked access to my account unless I accept their privacy rules, which means giving up GDPR protections. I worry that if I accept their rules now, I won't be protected anymore by GDPR, and that even if I delete my Facebook account in the future, that I won't be able to request my data to be fully deleted with full protections of GDPR. In other words, I worry that agreeing to their privacy policy will override GDPR and that I won't be able request to delete the data they have about me anymore. Is my worry justified?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: 
> I live in the EU and Facebook has blocked access to my account unless I accept their privacy rules, which means giving up GDPR protections.

Facebook operates in the EU and has EU data subjects, therefore Facebook is subject to GDPR.

You should be able to withdraw your consent. Article 7(3\) says:

> The data subject shall have the right to withdraw his or her consent at any time. The withdrawal of consent shall not affect the lawfulness of processing based on consent before its withdrawal. Prior to giving consent, the data subject shall be informed thereof. It shall be as easy to withdraw as to give consent.

4.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given information:

Question: An EU resident is considering deleting their Facebook account but is concerned about GDPR protections. Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding their rights under GDPR?

A) Once the user accepts Facebook's privacy policy, they permanently lose all GDPR protections, even after deleting their account.

B) The user can withdraw consent at any time, but this will not affect the lawfulness of data processing that occurred before the withdrawal.

C) Facebook is not subject to GDPR for users who have accepted their privacy policy, regardless of the user's location.

D) GDPR protections only apply if the user never accepts Facebook's privacy policy in the first place.

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: According to Article 7(3) of GDPR, data subjects have the right to withdraw their consent at any time. This withdrawal does not affect the lawfulness of processing based on consent before its withdrawal. Facebook, operating in the EU and having EU data subjects, is subject to GDPR regardless of whether a user accepts their privacy policy. The user retains their GDPR rights, including the right to withdraw consent, even after initially accepting the privacy policy. Options A, C, and D are incorrect as they misrepresent the application and persistence of GDPR protections.

documentation.title: Is texting landlord about lease renewal legally binding?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: I live in Ohio and was on a one\-year lease. The lease expired in May, but my landlord allowed me to go month\-to\-month after that. In July, I texted her asking if I could renew the lease. She replied that I could and that she would put together some documents to sign. This never happened.

For various reasons, I now need to move and was wondering if my text messages stating my intent to renew are legally binding.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Possibly
========

If the texts are sufficiently precise that they constitute offer and acceptance then they would create a contract notwithstanding that “some documents” were never provided.

First, your offer must have been sufficiently clear that it was open to acceptance by a simple “yes” or “ok”. Given that you had a lease, a simple offer to have another one would be enough as “on the same terms” is implied.

Second, she must have accepted your offer unconditionally. “Yes, I’ll put together some documents to sign” is an unconditional acceptance even if the documents never appear. “Yes, I’ll put together some documents to sign first” or “Yes, I’ll put together some documents with the terms” aren’t. The first is a conditional acceptance and the condition wasn’t met. The second is a rejection with an intention to make a counter\-offer that never eventuated.

Third, real estate is heavily regulated. There may be specific requirements (such as a particular form of contract, or that it be witnessed) that mean there is no binding lease even though there would be a contract at common law.

5.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given information:

Question: John, a tenant in Ohio, has been renting an apartment on a month-to-month basis after his original one-year lease expired. He texted his landlord, Sarah, asking to renew the lease. Sarah replied, "Sure, I'll draft a new lease agreement and send it over for you to sign." Two months later, no new lease agreement has been provided, but John wants to move out. Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding the legal status of John's tenancy?

A) John is bound to a new one-year lease based on the text message exchange, regardless of whether a formal agreement was signed.

B) John remains on a month-to-month tenancy since no new lease agreement was formally signed.

C) The text message exchange is not legally binding because real estate contracts must always be in writing and signed by both parties.

D) John is bound to a new lease only if Sarah can prove she sent the draft agreement within a reasonable timeframe.

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: While the text message exchange shows an intent to create a new lease, it lacks the specificity and formality typically required for a binding long-term lease agreement. Sarah's response indicates that she would draft a new lease agreement, which suggests that the text exchange itself was not intended to be the final agreement. Without a formal lease document signed by both parties, John's tenancy would default to the existing month-to-month arrangement. This allows John the flexibility to move out with proper notice as per month-to-month tenancy rules in Ohio. Options A and C are incorrect because text messages can form a contract in some cases, but here the exchange lacks sufficient detail and the clear intent for it to be the final agreement. Option D is incorrect because the binding nature of the agreement doesn't depend on Sarah's actions after the text exchange, but rather on the content and intent of the messages themselves.

documentation.title: What is the status of this patent?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: Recently I received a warning from someone who seller that says I am infringing on their utility patent.

While looking up their patent, I am seeing different information about the status.

1\) Source 1: Google Patents

Google Patents says the latest status is: 2019\-08\-12 Application status is Active.

2\) Source 2: USPTO <https://portal.uspto.gov/pair/PublicPair>

It says Status: Application Involved in Court Proceedings. Also, when I click on the "Image File Wrapper" tab, the latest update on 04\-08\-2019 shows that the patent was dismissed by the court

So is the patent rejected or accepted?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: That is *not at all* what USPTO is telling you. Courts do not simply "dismiss" patents \- that isn't a terminology you'd ever see used for a patent that was found to be invalid.

Timeline of events:

* United Industries Corporation brought a suit against the owner of the patent, claiming unpatentability.
* That case went to trial, and the court found the claim to be invalid and that UIC failed to show unpatentability.
* UIC appealed that decision to the Court of Appeals.
* The Court of Appeals dismissed the case because both parties agreed to its dismissal (it's possible they reached some external agreement we don't know about).

As far as I can tell, at this moment, the patent is active.

6.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: A company receives a warning about infringing on a utility patent. Upon investigating the patent's status, they find conflicting information. Google Patents shows the status as "Active" as of 2019-08-12, while the USPTO website indicates "Application Involved in Court Proceedings" and mentions a dismissal by the court. What is the most likely current status of this patent?

A) The patent has been invalidated by the court
B) The patent application is still pending approval
C) The patent is active and enforceable
D) The patent has been abandoned by the applicant

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The correct answer is C, the patent is active and enforceable. The information provided can be misleading without proper context. The USPTO status "Application Involved in Court Proceedings" doesn't mean the patent is invalid or unapproved. The court dismissal mentioned likely refers to a lawsuit regarding the patent, not the patent's validity itself. 

The timeline shows that a company (United Industries Corporation) challenged the patent's validity, but the court found the claim to be invalid and that UIC failed to show unpatentability. An appeal was later dismissed by mutual agreement of both parties. This sequence of events actually reinforces the patent's validity.

The Google Patents status of "Active" is the most current and accurate representation of the patent's status. The conflicting information is a result of complex legal proceedings that ultimately did not invalidate the patent. Therefore, the patent remains active and enforceable.

documentation.title: Public procurement laws or regulations similar to HIPAA or PCI?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: United States here, and potentially also involving two states, New York and Vermont.

If a business is a vendor that sells goods to the federal government (as a GSA awarded contractor) and also sells goods to state procurement agencies (New York \- Office of General Services, or OGS; and in Vermont its the Office of Purchasing \& Contracting), they have to maintain inventory data and regularly submit updates to the agency they have an award with.

In a similar vein to how HIPAA regulates businesses who maintain health data, and PCI regulates businesses that collect payment information from consumers, are there any similar regulations that govern what such GSA/OGS/OPC vendors can do with their inventory data?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: I've done quite a bit of digging through GSA regs and don't see anything indicating that such rules exist. The [various portals](https://vsc.gsa.gov/marketing/advantageOptions.cfm) for relaying such information to GSA don't indicate that there's any kind of meaningful restrictions on how vendors handle the data they submit.

I suspect this is a reflection of the idea that there's no real point forcing businesses to spend more money protecting their own information than they think is cost\-efficient. A hospital or credit\-card company with lax security endangers the private information of thousands or millions of customers who expect privacy, but a vendor who fails to secure his inventory data generally risks exposing only his own information, which may not even be secret in the first place. After all, GSA is but one customer for most vendors, who can't sell their products if they can't disclose their inventory and prices.

7.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given documentation:

Question: Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding regulations on inventory data for businesses that are vendors to federal and state government agencies in the United States?

A) Vendors must comply with strict regulations similar to HIPAA for health data or PCI for payment information when handling their inventory data.

B) The GSA (General Services Administration) imposes specific security measures on vendors to protect their inventory data from breaches.

C) Vendors are generally not subject to special regulations regarding the handling of their own inventory data submitted to government agencies.

D) State procurement agencies in New York and Vermont have uniform guidelines for vendors on inventory data protection that mirror federal standards.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The documentation suggests that there are no specific regulations governing how vendors handle their inventory data submitted to government agencies like GSA, OGS, or OPC. Unlike HIPAA for health data or PCI for payment information, inventory data is generally considered the vendor's own information and doesn't involve sensitive customer data. The lack of regulation is likely because vendors are expected to protect their own business information as they see fit, and the exposure of inventory data primarily affects the vendor rather than individual privacy. Additionally, much of this information may already be public as part of the vendor's marketing efforts. Options A, B, and D are incorrect as they imply the existence of regulations or uniform guidelines that are not supported by the given information.

documentation.title: Copyright vs. right to attribution
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: [*Feist Publication, Inc. v. Rural Telephone Service Co.*, 499 U.S. 340, 349\-50 (1991\) (citations omitted)](https://ilt.eff.org/index.php/Copyright) gives the primary purpose of copyright:

> The primary objective of copyright is not to reward the labor of authors, but \[t]o promote the Progress of Science and useful Arts. To this end, copyright assures authors the right to their original expression, but encourages others to build freely upon the ideas and information conveyed by a work. This result is neither unfair nor unfortunate. It is the means by which copyright advances the progress of science and art.

According to this, it seems copyright is not as much for protecting the author's right to allow others to copy their work as it is to protect against distortions, misrepresentations, or misattributions of the work.

Thus, is copyright really for protecting the author's right to attribution?  
(like a [CC BY license](https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/)?)

Is the right to attribution contained within copyright?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Copyright does not contain the right to attribution (except with respect to authors of visual arts at [17 USC 106A](https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/17/106A)).

A copyright owner has the exclusive right to reproduce a work, create derivative works, distribute copies, etc. ([17 USC §106](https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/17/106)).

As we already answered [here](https://law.stackexchange.com/questions/16411/what-are-the-differences-and-similarities-between-copyright-and-licensing), when a copyright owner gives somebody else permission to do some of those things, the copyright owner can attach a condition to that permission. A common condition is that the licensee give credit to the the original creator.

With respect to visual arts, the attribution right gives the *author* the right to "prevent the use of his or her name as the author of the work of visual art in the event of a distortion, mutilation, or other modification of the work which would be prejudicial to his or her honor or reputation." 17 USC §106A(a)(2\)

8.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: According to U.S. copyright law, which of the following statements is most accurate regarding the right to attribution?

A) Copyright inherently includes the right to attribution for all types of creative works.
B) The right to attribution is only granted to authors of visual arts under specific circumstances.
C) Copyright primarily exists to protect an author's right to attribution.
D) All copyright licenses must include a requirement for attribution.

Correct Answer: B

Explanation:
A) is incorrect because copyright does not inherently include the right to attribution for all types of works. The provided information explicitly states that copyright does not contain the right to attribution, except in specific cases for visual arts.

B) is correct. According to 17 USC 106A, authors of visual arts have the right to prevent the use of their name on works that have been distorted, mutilated, or modified in a way that would be prejudicial to their honor or reputation. This is a limited right to attribution specifically for visual arts.

C) is incorrect. The primary purpose of copyright, as stated in Feist Publication, Inc. v. Rural Telephone Service Co., is "to promote the Progress of Science and useful Arts," not to protect attribution rights.

D) is incorrect. While attribution can be a condition of a copyright license (such as in Creative Commons BY licenses), it is not a requirement for all copyright licenses. The copyright owner has the flexibility to include or exclude attribution requirements when granting permissions.

documentation.title: To what is the judge in the Lina E. trial referring to by "deplorable deficiencies in recent trials of far-right extremists"?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: [It is in the news](https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-65801804) that there have been protests after the sentencing of Lina E for attacks on neo\-Nazis. [Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trial_of_Lina_E.#Arrest_and_trial) quoting [this German language news article](https://www.fr.de/politik/antifa-news-lina-e-prozess-urteil-verkuendung-demo-leipzig-dresden-kassel-linksextremismus-zr-92312816.html) says:

> Hans Schlüter\-Staats, the Higher Regional Court of Dresden judge overseeing the trial, stated that "opposing right\-wing extremists is a respectable motive" and that there had been "deplorable" deficiencies in recent trials of far\-right extremists

To what cases is the judge referring to here?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: 
> To what cases is the judge referring to here?

None: neither the quoted article ([2023\-06\-02 05:57: Prozess gegen Lina E.: Stadt Leipzig verbietet Solidaritäts\-Demonstration](https://web.archive.org/web/20230602053810/https://www.fr.de/politik/news-lina-e-prozess-urteil-verkuendung-demo-leipzig-dresden-kassel-linksextremismus-antifa-zr-92312816.html)) given in the [english version of Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trial_of_Lina_E.#Arrest_and_trial) nor the german Wikipedia version ([Dresdner Linksextremismusprozess – Wikipedia](https://de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dresdner_Linksextremismusprozess) uses the quote given in the english version.

In the article itself, the name 'Hans Schlueter\-Staats' is used only once:

> The arrest warrant against them will be suspended against conditions, said **Hans Schlueter\-Staats**, presiding judge of the State Protection Chamber at the Dresden Higher Regional Court, on Wednesday evening at the end of the verdict. She only has to serve the remainder of the sentence if the verdict becomes final.

Assume that, for whatever reason, someone added a fabricated quote, in the Wikipedia page, that is **not** contained in the given source hoping that nobody would notice (either because the reader can't read German or simply wouldn't look).

It would be **very strange** for a judge whos primary duty, in a civil law system, is to *read the law as written*, to give a personal opinion about previous rulings (which was the reason I looked: to read the exact German text).

Whoever fabricated that quote was obviously unaware of this **or** didn't care hoping that others would simply assume it to be correct due the given source of a newspaper that has a reputation as being a reliable source.

9.answer:
Here's a multi-choice question based on the information provided:

Question: In a legal context, what lesson can be drawn from the fabricated quote attributed to Judge Hans Schlüter-Staats in the Wikipedia article about the trial of Lina E?

A) Judges in civil law systems routinely comment on the outcomes of previous cases during ongoing trials.

B) Wikipedia is always a reliable primary source for legal information and direct quotes from court proceedings.

C) The inability to verify information in a foreign language makes it immune to scrutiny in academic or legal contexts.

D) Critical evaluation of sources, including cross-referencing and language verification, is crucial when dealing with legal information online.

Correct Answer: D

Explanation: The correct answer is D. This case demonstrates the importance of critically evaluating sources, especially for legal information found online. The fabricated quote attributed to Judge Hans Schlüter-Staats was not present in the original German source, yet it appeared in the English Wikipedia article. This highlights the need for cross-referencing information, verifying translations, and being cautious about accepting information at face value, particularly when it involves legal matters or quotes from judicial figures.

Answer A is incorrect because judges in civil law systems typically focus on interpreting the law as written, not commenting on previous cases. Answer B is false, as this example shows that Wikipedia can contain inaccurate information and should not be considered a primary source. Answer C is also incorrect, as the inability to verify foreign language sources should increase scrutiny, not reduce it.

documentation.title: In what circumstances does an investment advisor have to register as a money transmitter?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: As far as I understand it, an SEC\-registered investment advisor that doesn't hold the client's assets doesn't need extra regulation pertaining to custody. If a robo\-advisor like Betterment (although I understand that they're Broker\-Dealer\-registered) is registered as an RIA and sends client orders straight to the exchange through a broker like Interactive Brokers, do they have to register as a money transmitter? How do the laws change for assets like crypto (sending an order straight to Binance, Coinbase, etc)

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: A Money Transmitter (MT) is a subset of Money Services Businesses (MSBs) according to the definition of an MSB ([31 §1010\.100(ff)](https://www.fincen.gov/money-services-business-definition)). Exempted from inclusion in MSB definition is "a person registered with, and functionally regulated or examined by, the SEC." As an SEC\-registered investment advisor, it sounds like such a robo\-advisor would not need to register as a money transmitter business as well.

10.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: A new fintech startup is developing a robo-advisor platform that will be registered with the SEC as an investment advisor. The platform will not hold client assets directly but will send client orders to exchanges through established brokers. Which of the following statements is correct regarding the startup's regulatory obligations?

A) The startup must register as both an investment advisor and a money transmitter.
B) The startup is exempt from registering as a money transmitter due to its SEC registration.
C) The startup must register as a money transmitter only if it deals with cryptocurrency assets.
D) The startup is required to register as a money services business but not as a money transmitter.

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: According to the information provided, entities "registered with, and functionally regulated or examined by, the SEC" are exempt from the definition of Money Services Businesses (MSBs), which includes money transmitters. Since the startup is registered as an SEC investment advisor and does not hold client assets directly, it would be exempt from having to register as a money transmitter. This exemption applies regardless of whether the platform deals with traditional securities or cryptocurrencies, as long as it maintains its SEC registration and doesn't engage in direct custody of client assets.

documentation.title: US laws: shooting an undercover cop
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: So this is in the interest of storytelling and writing.

So we have cop A who is undercover and acting as mobster B's right hand man.

Then we have bar owner C who closed down the bar, and is alone in it doing inventory 2 hours after closing, all alone.

B and A come in the bar (forcibly, since it was closed, but quietly) and surprise C. B want to threaten C into paying protection money, but C refuses, so B and A (who is undercover) are trashing the place and threatening C with death.

C then quickly pulls out a gun and shoots both of them dead.

Would C be in any trouble? Seeing as how it was self defense and he didn't know that A was an undercover cop.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Laws that add special penalties to killing a police officer require that the accused knows that the victim is a police officer, for example [DC 22\-2106](https://code.dccouncil.us/dc/council/code/sections/22-2106.html) (emphasis mine)

> (a) Whoever, with deliberate and premeditated malice, and **with knowledge or reason to know that the victim is a law enforcement officer or public safety employee**, kills any law enforcement officer...

A prosecution would need to show beyond a reasonable doubt that the accused knew the victim was an undercover police officer to convict them under this statute. In the case presented, it seems unlikely that the bartender could be convicted under such a statute, even without consideration of a possible self\-defense argument.

11.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given documentation:

Question: In a scenario where an undercover police officer is killed during a criminal act they were participating in as part of their cover, which of the following statements is most accurate regarding potential legal consequences for the killer?

A) The killer would automatically be charged with the special offense of killing a police officer, regardless of their knowledge of the officer's status.

B) The killer could only be charged with the special offense of killing a police officer if there was clear evidence they knew the victim's true identity.

C) The killer would face no legal consequences at all if they claimed self-defense, regardless of the circumstances.

D) The killer would be immune from prosecution because the officer was engaging in criminal activity at the time.

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: The correct answer is B. According to the documentation, laws that impose special penalties for killing a police officer typically require that the accused had knowledge or reason to know that the victim was a law enforcement officer. In this case, the prosecution would need to prove beyond a reasonable doubt that the killer knew the victim was an undercover police officer to convict them under such a statute. 

Option A is incorrect because the killer's knowledge of the officer's status is crucial, not automatic. 

Option C is overly broad; while self-defense might be a valid argument, it doesn't guarantee freedom from all legal consequences without consideration of the specific circumstances. 

Option D is incorrect because an officer's undercover work, even if it involves participating in criminal activities, doesn't automatically grant immunity to their killer.

The question tests understanding of the nuanced legal requirements for special charges related to killing law enforcement officers, particularly in complex scenarios involving undercover work.

documentation.title: New York City- Tenant Rights
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: I have a question regarding tenant's rights under a leased property; I can't seem to find the answer anywhere online.

***What are the obligations of a tenant in a 1yr lease to provide notice of vacating the premises by the end of the lease, if there is no language in the lease describing such a notice? In other words, is there New York City or New York State law that requires a minimum notice to be given to the landlord if the lease is not to be renewed?***

Any help is greatly appreciated! I have tried to look in Article 7 under real property laws (Landlord and Tenant laws) but cannot find any relevant language!

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: 
> What are the obligations of a tenant in a 1yr lease to provide notice of vacating the premises by the end of the lease, if there is no language in the lease describing such a notice?

Apparently there is none as long as the tenant leaves the property by the expiration date. The closest statutory provision in this regard is [section 232\-C of article 7](https://www.nysenate.gov/legislation/laws/RPP/232-C), which addresses leases of "*term longer than one month*". That statute does not require the tenant to give notice.

In the more difficult scenario of a tenant requesting to be released from a lease, [section 226\-B](https://www.nysenate.gov/legislation/laws/RPP/226-B) mentions a 30\-day period of forced release if the landlord *unreasonably* withholds consent. However, a tenant's decision not to renew a lease does not need landlord's consent, whence the guidance from section 226\-B seems unnecessary.

12.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given documentation:

Question: A tenant in New York City has a one-year lease agreement that is about to expire. The lease does not contain any language regarding notice of vacating the premises. Which of the following statements is correct regarding the tenant's obligations?

A) The tenant must provide at least 30 days' notice before the lease expiration date.
B) The tenant must provide at least 60 days' notice before the lease expiration date.
C) The tenant is not required to provide any notice as long as they vacate by the lease expiration date.
D) The tenant must request the landlord's consent to not renew the lease at least 30 days before expiration.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: According to the information provided, there is no statutory requirement for a tenant to give notice of vacating the premises at the end of a one-year lease in New York City or New York State, if the lease itself does not specify such a requirement. Section 232-C of Article 7 in New York's Real Property Law, which addresses leases longer than one month, does not mandate that tenants provide notice. As long as the tenant vacates the property by the expiration date of the lease, they have fulfilled their obligations. Options A and B are incorrect as they specify notice periods that are not required by law in this situation. Option D is also incorrect because a tenant does not need the landlord's consent to not renew a lease that is expiring.

documentation.title: Is it legal to put a billboard on residential property?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: 
> A billboard is put on top of a person's roof or on his vacant land. It is zoned residential. This person lives on a main road and the billboard is visible to cars travelling on it. He hasn't received permits or licenses to do so.

1. Is this legal on a federal level according to U.S. laws?
2. Is this legal in all states or do some states prohibit this?
3. What about county and local laws?
4. Do some counties and cities have ordinances that prohibit
residential billboards?
5. Or is a person allowed to construct signs on their own personal
property as it is their right to do so with their land as they please?
6. If this is unlawful, what are some of the potential consequences
that the landowner could face? Would they just be fines and how
large might those fines be?
7. Should this person be researching all local county and city
ordinances to see if this is legal in his area, or should this be
considered fine anywhere within the USA?
8. Does it matter what size the billboard is? For instance, does a 7'x7' billboard carry less lawful risk than a 30'x30' billboard?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Laws regarding billboards and advertising are very local in nature and are typically handled under city/county zoning ordinances. Start with calling your local county zoning office. They will tell you the city/county laws regarding your particular residential zoning overlay, if city or state laws supersede county laws, and recent changes in law that might matter and if the sign might be grandfathered.

There can be different types of "residential" zoning and the city/county will tell you this; some allow limited commercial use and signage, and some don't. The housing subdivision you are in may also have covenants; you'll know if there are covenants if you received information when you bought property in that subdivision.

**1,2,3,4,8:** These depend on local laws.

**5:** Very generally speaking, land owners typically do not have absolute rights to land usage; that is the rationale behind zoning laws (among others, like health and public safety, building codes, national defense, etc.), because some types of land usage impact adjacent users and the general public.

**6, 7:** Potential consequences include fines and requirements to take the billboard down, but again, those possibilities are very localized. The size of the billboard could come into play; again, this will be very localized. Some signage may be grandfathered, too.

In order for the city/county to look at the situation and possibly take action, you may have to file a written protest with the zoning office; they would help with the process. You may have to present your case at a public city council or county commission meeting, but that basically involves saying such and such is happening and you want the city/county attorney to look into relevant laws. It would help your case if you had a list of names of others in the area who are also unhappy about the billboard. I doubt you will need legal representation to lodge a protest, but if it comes to that, Google for free legal aid in your area.

If the city/county attorney *won't* take action (which is possible, as this involves prosecutorial discretion as to if the city/county wants to press the issue with the landowner), you can look for free legal aid in your area and consider your options.

13.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the information provided:

Question: A homeowner in a residential area wants to erect a large billboard on their property visible from a main road. Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding the legality of this action?

A) Federal law prohibits all billboards in residential areas, so this would be illegal anywhere in the USA.

B) As long as the billboard is on private property, the homeowner has the right to construct it regardless of local zoning laws.

C) The legality depends primarily on local zoning ordinances and regulations, which vary widely between different cities and counties.

D) Only billboards over 30'x30' in size require permits, so smaller signs are always allowed in residential areas.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The legality of erecting a billboard in a residential area is primarily governed by local zoning laws and ordinances, which can vary significantly between different jurisdictions. There is no federal law that universally prohibits billboards in residential areas. While property owners have certain rights, these are not absolute and are subject to local zoning restrictions. The size of the billboard may be a factor, but this is also determined by local regulations, not a universal rule. To determine if the billboard is legal, the homeowner would need to research their specific local zoning laws and potentially obtain necessary permits.

documentation.title: Is there a polite and thorough way to request disclosures from my dentist about who is profiting from certain products or services?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: I had a dental appointment this morning, and the dentist (as per usual) insisted that I get an NTI night guard and a Philips Sonicare. I politely said 'no' as I have the last 6 visits, but the insistence is starting to creep me out a bit. 

I had a previous dentist who sold me a night guard for $500 that really messed up my jaw. When I confronted him on why he was pushing something so hard that the insurance didn't cover (for good reason!), he flatly told me "I don't make a dime selling night guards, this is just an option we provide to customers who would benefit." I found this very hard to believe, \- obviously there's some lack of specificity in the terms "I" and "make money" \- so I let it go. 

So what I want now is a polite way I can ask my current dentist (or possible future dentist) a question such that they can either 1\) decline to answer or 2\) answer it clearly and unequivocally. 

EDIT: I'll try to be more specific: I want to ask my dentist : "Is Philips paying you to sell me their product?" in a way that will put them on the hook for fraud if they intentionally equivocate. (They could say "Well, technically, I don't get paid directly by Philips, but this information is reported to the dental management company, which has a contract with Philips, and the management company gives me quarterly performance reviews which affect my salary") If they lie, and I buy the product, and later discover that they lied, then they have committed fraud (this is my understanding.) I'm not sure the exact form of the answer I'm looking for, but certainly reading the language of the standard conflict of interest forms is not something I'm about to do to a dentist. 

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: There is no law that helps you. The dentist is under no obligation to tell you about the business and has no duty to be honest with you about such questions. Unless you have a private agreement, for example:

> Dentist: Would you like to buy a toothbrush?  
> 
>  You: Yes I will, but only if you do not profit from it.  
> 
>  Dentist: I do not profit.  
> 
>  You: OK, I will buy it.

If the dentist is lying, this would constitute fraud in the inducement, which you can research if you like. Keep in mind that your remedy is litigation.

The nightguard is a different question. Unnecessary appliances and procedures have their own set of consequences, but that is not your question.

14.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the LawStackExchange documentation:

Question: According to the legal information provided, which of the following statements is most accurate regarding a dentist's obligation to disclose financial incentives for recommending specific products?

A) Dentists are legally required to disclose any financial incentives they receive for recommending specific brands or products.

B) Dentists can be held liable for fraud if they fail to disclose financial incentives when directly asked by a patient.

C) Dentists have no legal obligation to disclose financial incentives unless there is a specific agreement with the patient.

D) Patients have a right to know about any financial incentives, and dentists must provide this information upon request.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The correct answer is C. According to the information provided, dentists have no legal obligation to disclose financial incentives or profit arrangements for recommending products, unless there is a specific agreement with the patient. The documentation states that "There is no law that helps you" and "The dentist is under no obligation to tell you about the business and has no duty to be honest with you about such questions." The only scenario where the dentist could potentially be held accountable is if there was a specific agreement made between the dentist and patient, as illustrated in the example dialogue. Options A, B, and D are incorrect because they imply legal obligations or rights that are not supported by the given information.

documentation.title: What are the regulatory equivalents of "prosecute" and "convict"?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: If I understand correctly, the terms "prosecute," "convict," "guilty," and "innocent" are only used in criminal cases. What are the equivalents in cases of civil violations, such as traffic infractions or violations of radio regulations?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: For a civil infraction, the typical term is found *responsible/not responsible*.

For example, Michigan [MCL 600\.113(1\)(b)](http://www.legislature.mi.gov/(S(4m5zzvcltoeco5jt2ad4cnti))/mileg.aspx?page=GetObject&objectname=mcl-600-113)

> (b) "Civil infraction action" means a civil action in which the defendant is alleged to be responsible for a civil infraction.

For violations of Federal regulations, as in the FCC example, the term is found *in violation/not in violation*.

[47 CFR § 95\.313(b)](https://www.law.cornell.edu/cfr/text/47/95.313)

> If a Federal court finds that a Personal Radio Service station operator has willfully and knowingly violated any FCC rule, the operator may be fined up to $500 for each violation...

15.answer:
Here's a difficult multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: In a case involving a potential violation of Federal Communications Commission (FCC) regulations by a Personal Radio Service station operator, which of the following terms would most accurately describe the outcome if the operator was found to have broken the rules?

A) The operator was convicted of violating FCC regulations
B) The operator was found guilty of an FCC infraction
C) The operator was found responsible for an FCC violation
D) The operator was found in violation of FCC regulations

Correct Answer: D

Explanation: 
The question tests understanding of legal terminology in different contexts. For criminal cases, terms like "convict" and "guilty" are used, but these are not appropriate for regulatory violations. In civil infractions, the term "responsible" is often used. However, for violations of federal regulations specifically, such as FCC rules, the correct terminology is "found in violation" or "not in violation."

Option A is incorrect because "convicted" is a term used in criminal cases, not regulatory violations.
Option B is incorrect because "guilty" is also a criminal law term and "infraction" is more commonly used in civil cases, not federal regulatory matters.
Option C is close, as "responsible" is used in civil infractions, but it's not the most precise term for federal regulatory violations.
Option D is correct, as it uses the specific terminology "found in violation" which is appropriate for FCC and other federal regulatory matters.

documentation.title: Is it legal to use someone else's credit card with permission?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: Is it legal to use someone else's credit card with their permission? What about forging a signature, also with permission?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: It is legal for you to use another person's card with their permission, since it is not statutorily forbidden and you have no contractual obligation to the card company. It may be contractually forbidden (by the card company) to let your card be used in that way, though I've never heard of any such prohibition. It is not forgery, under [ORS 165\.007](https://oregon.public.law/statutes/ors_165.007): there is no intent to harm. There is also credit card specific [ORC 165\.055](https://oregon.public.law/statutes/ors_165.055), which also does not apply because use of the card is with permission of the issuee.

16.answer:
Here's a difficult multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: John allows his friend Sarah to use his credit card to make a purchase online. Sarah uses John's card information but signs John's name on the digital signature field. Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding this situation?

A) Both John and Sarah have committed credit card fraud, as it's illegal to use someone else's credit card under any circumstances.

B) Sarah's actions are legal because she had John's permission, but John has violated his agreement with the credit card company by allowing someone else to use his card.

C) Sarah's use of the card is legal, but her signing of John's name constitutes forgery, regardless of John's permission.

D) Both the use of the credit card and the signing of John's name are legal in this scenario, assuming John gave permission for both actions.

Correct Answer: D

Explanation: According to the provided information, it is legal to use another person's credit card with their permission, as there is no statutory prohibition against it. The potential contractual violation between the cardholder and the credit card company is not addressed in the question. Furthermore, signing someone else's name with their permission does not constitute forgery in this context, as there is no intent to harm or defraud. The key elements here are John's permission for both the use of the card and the signature. Therefore, both actions are legal in this scenario, making option D the most accurate statement.

documentation.title: Does California's Information Practices Act (IPA) of 1977 apply to individuals after death?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: I'm in the midst of researching a person who was born in 1892 and died in 1969 in California. The subject has no living heirs.

I've requested documents from the California Department of Consumers Affairs regarding a license held by this individual when they were alive. 

The state has returned many valuable documents but much of the useful info has been redacted. For example, the individuals employer names and the individuals work/home addresses have been redacted. 

The state is citing California Civil Code sections 1798\.1 and 1798\.3 as to why the information may not be released.

I've read the code and it defined the protected individual as a "natural person" \- but I'm unable to determine if a deceased person is still considered a natural person. 

In short, is there any legal argument for requesting that the information, which is nearing 100 years old, should be released?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Dead people are "natural people" (the term is used to distinguish corporations and so on). There does not seem to be any exception made in the case the individual is dead or has been dead for some time, other than to conservators, beneficiaries, or for statistical purposes (etc.), or with permission of next of kin.

The [Public Records Act](https://leginfo.legislature.ca.gov/faces/codes_displayText.xhtml?lawCode=GOV&division=7.&title=1.&part=&chapter=3.5.&article=1.) limits disclosure of personal information but has an explicit exemption

> If the subject whose privacy is to be protected is deceased, an heir,
>  beneficiary, designated immediate family member, or authorized legal
>  representative of the deceased subject whose privacy is to be
>  protected.

That means, protection of privacy of a dead person was a legislative concern 9 years before the Information Practices Act was enacted. The laws are not exactly the same, but since both laws cover government records and their disclosure, there may be similar "privacy concerns" reasoning underlying both laws.

17.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given information:

Question: Under California law, which of the following statements is most accurate regarding the release of personal information for a deceased individual who died in 1969?

A) Personal information can be freely released after 50 years from the date of death.
B) The California Public Records Act allows release of all information for statistical purposes without restriction.
C) Personal information remains protected under the Information Practices Act, even for deceased individuals with no living heirs.
D) The California Civil Code explicitly states that privacy protections cease upon an individual's death.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The California Information Practices Act (Civil Code sections 1798.1 and 1798.3) protects personal information of "natural persons," which includes deceased individuals. There is no automatic time limit for when this protection expires after death. The Public Records Act, while a separate law, demonstrates that the legislature was concerned with protecting the privacy of deceased individuals. The lack of living heirs does not change the application of these privacy protections. While there are some exceptions for release of information to specific parties (like heirs or for statistical purposes), these are limited and do not allow for unrestricted public release of personal information, even many years after an individual's death.

documentation.title: Do US landline carriers have safe harbor for carrying illegal calls?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: I am curious to know if US landline carriers have safe harbor for carrying illegal calls? That is, are the carriers somehow immune from an action when they carry illegal calls on their network?

The changing tide and specific details are (1\) carriers are accepting and completing calls from known robocallers and other miscreants, and (2\) the FTC's 2017 ruling that carriers can block the traffic at the network level.

The insight for (1\) is, carriers have available lists of some robocallers and other miscreants. Two lists are (a) the [FTC Do Not Call](https://www.ftc.gov/site-information/open-government/data-sets/do-not-call-data) data files, and (b) reports of harassing calls from some robocallers and other miscreants via Unlawful Call Centers (i.e., \*57\).

The change for (2\) is from the FTC. It is Advanced Methods to Target and Eliminate Unlawful Robocalls, CG Docket No. 17\-59, published in FCC\-CIRC1703\-01\. Specifically (D)(8\) states:

> To aid the Strike Force and other providers’ call blocking efforts,
>  the Consumer and Governmental Affairs Bureau (Bureau) released a
>  Public Notice on September 30, 2016 clarifying that voice service
>  providers may block calls using a spoofed Caller ID number if the
>  number’s subscriber requests that they do so.\[26] The 2016 Guidance PN
>  built on the Commission’s earlier clarification,\[27] which, among
>  other things, clarified that nothing in the Communications Act
>  prohibits voice service providers from offering call blocking tools to
>  those consumers who request such services.\[28] Following from that
>  initial guidance, the Strike Force Report sought additional
>  clarification regarding the permissibility of certain
>  provider\-initiated call blocking.\[29] Specifically, it sought
>  clarification that 1\) providers may block calls where the Caller ID
>  shows an unassigned number, and 2\) providers may block calls that the
>  provider has determined to be illegal robocalls, so long as the
>  provider takes reasonable steps to confirm that the calls are illegal.

And to state the obvious, some of the robocalls violate the Telephone Consumer Protection Act and Truth in Caller ID Act of 2009\. Additionally, if the inbound call is carried over a person's or business' VoIP or computer network, then it could violate Computer Fraud and Abuse Act also.

And I am also aware of the [illegal spying campaign carried out with the US government](https://www.eff.org/nsa-spying). However, it literally took an act of congress to let the carriers off the hook for that illegal activity.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Yes. As a utility, telephone carriers (both landline and cell carriers) are immune from unlawful communications crossing over their networks. The responsibility of any illicit form of speech (such that there is in the United States. The most common is falsely calling 911 (true threat doctrine)), though I'm sure someone somewhere has discussed criminal actions over the phone as well.

Because the public would be disserviced from utilities discriminating against customers who might abuse the system to communicate illicit messages (if for no other reason than they may have to call 911 for an actual bona fide need), the governments will usually grant immunity from responsibility from illicit use of the service by a user. Just as one would not hold a phone company liable for a bomb threat that used their network infrastructure to reach it's recipient, an electric company or water company is not responsible for the use of their services to create artificial sunlight or water plants in a drug grow house.

18.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given information:

Question: Which of the following statements best describes the legal status of US landline carriers regarding illegal calls transmitted through their networks?

A) Landline carriers are always liable for any illegal calls transmitted through their networks.

B) Landline carriers have no immunity and can be sued for any illegal activity conducted using their services.

C) Landline carriers have safe harbor protection and are generally immune from legal action for illegal calls transmitted through their networks, unless explicitly authorized by Congress.

D) Landline carriers are only immune from legal action if they can prove they took active steps to prevent illegal calls.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The correct answer is C. According to the information provided, US landline carriers generally have safe harbor protection and are immune from legal action for illegal calls transmitted through their networks. This immunity is granted because utilities like telephone carriers are not expected to discriminate against customers who might abuse the system, as this could potentially prevent legitimate use of the service (such as emergency calls). The immunity can only be revoked through explicit acts of Congress, as evidenced by the case of the illegal spying campaign mentioned in the text. Options A and B are incorrect because they state that carriers have no immunity, which contradicts the information given. Option D is incorrect because the carriers' immunity is not conditional on them taking active steps to prevent illegal calls, although recent FTC rulings have clarified that they are allowed to block certain types of calls if they choose to do so.

documentation.title: Use of "evidence" like ISP metadata in divorce cases in Australia
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: There have been mentions in Australian news recently that internet "metadata" which was ostensibly collected for national security purposes may be made available for civil cases ([abc.net.au](http://mobile.abc.net.au/news/2017-01-05/telco-industry-pushes-for-metadata-collection-changes/8162896?pfmredir=sm)). People's primary concern is that this could be used by rightsholders in copyright cases, but there are also mentions of it being used in divorce cases. 

My question is why any evidence is necessary in divorce related matters in Australian courts \- my understanding of "no fault" divorce was that no "evidence" is relevant, and a divorce requires nothing more than one party choosing to pursue one. If this is the case, why would evidence come into play? Without "no fault" divorce I could see records of internet use or other evidence being used to prove breaches of trust/pre\-nuptial agreements, but if that's not required, why are people talking about internet metadata being used in these cases?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: It isn't relevant to the divorce, it may be relevant to post\-divorce custody arrangements and/or associated domestic violence issues.

Divorces are often acrimonious and the Family Court has to consider conflicting claims that one or the other of the parents is violent or otherwise unfit to have custody or that court orders are not being complied with. Metadata could be used to support or oppose such assertions.

19.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given documentation:

Question: In the context of Australian divorce proceedings, why might internet metadata be considered relevant despite Australia's "no-fault" divorce system?

A) To prove grounds for divorce, such as infidelity or abandonment
B) To determine the division of assets between divorcing parties
C) To support or oppose claims related to child custody and domestic violence issues
D) To establish the date of separation for legal purposes

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: 
A is incorrect because Australia has a "no-fault" divorce system, meaning proof of wrongdoing is not required to obtain a divorce.
B is incorrect as metadata is unlikely to be directly relevant to asset division.
C is correct because, as stated in the documentation, metadata could be used to support or oppose claims about a parent's fitness for custody or compliance with court orders in post-divorce arrangements.
D is incorrect as the date of separation is typically established through other means and is not the primary use of metadata in divorce-related cases.

documentation.title: Are on-duty officers allowed to lie about their identity?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: This is a follow\-up to [this question](https://law.stackexchange.com/questions/81754/is-it-legal-to-release-the-identities-of-investigators-of-an-active-case/81758#81758). In it, I talk about how I see it as problematic that the identities of LEOs investigating an active case can be publicized. If that case concerns a serial killer, or perhaps members of organized crime, it seems like the investigators could become the target of assassination, threats, blackmail and bribery.

According to [this article](https://www.lawfareblog.com/can-law-enforcement-officers-refuse-identify-themselves), LEOs are not mandated by federal or state law to disclose their identity, though this may be mandated at a municipal level. Given I'm writing a fictive work set in NYC, I'm specifically asking the following questions, in relation to that jurisdiction in particular:

1. Are on\-duty officers required to identify themselves in NYC?
2. Are on\-duty officers allowed to lie about their identity in NYC?
3. Are on\-duty officers allowed to show a fake badge in NYC?

If the answer to 1\. and 2\. is 'yes', but the answer to 3\. is 'no', perhaps they're allowed to swiftly flash their badges whilst stating a false identity?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: No
--

At least, not in all circumstances.

Obviously, a uniformed police officer is automatically identifiable: and usually displays a precinct number, badge number and name (depending on the uniform). A plainclothes officer, not so much.

In most circumstances, a police officer is not required to identify themselves as such. This includes normal interactions, like buying a sandwich for lunch and actions that might be thought of as "police work": investigation, surveillance, and undercover work. However, when they are executing a "police power", like entering premises subject to a warrant or probable cause, making an arrest, or issuing an order they need to identify themselves as a police officer \- not doing so can lead to confusion: always a bad thing where firearms might be involved.

As to lying, a police officer has no general duty to be truthful except in very narrow circumstances. They must tell you if you are under arrest if you ask and they must read you your rights if they place you under arrest. Aside from that, they can lie their asses off.

A police officer could use a fake badge if the circumstances warranted it. For example, if they were investigating fellow police officers in an undercover role.

20.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given information:

Question: Detective Smith is working undercover in NYC to investigate a potential corruption case within the police department. Which of the following actions would be legally permissible for him to take?

A) Refuse to identify himself as a police officer when asked by a suspect
B) Use a fake badge to pose as an officer from a different precinct
C) Lie about his identity when questioned by fellow officers
D) All of the above

Correct Answer: D

Explanation: 
A) is correct because police officers in NYC are not required to identify themselves in all circumstances, especially during undercover work.

B) is correct because the documentation states that a police officer could use a fake badge if the circumstances warranted it, such as investigating fellow officers in an undercover role.

C) is correct because police officers have no general duty to be truthful except in very narrow circumstances, which don't apply in this scenario.

D) is the correct answer as all of the above actions would be legally permissible for Detective Smith in this undercover investigation scenario. The question tests the understanding of the complexities surrounding police identity disclosure, the use of deception in investigations, and the legal boundaries of undercover work.

documentation.title: Are there recommended steps for preparing for a divorce mediation meeting?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: Are there recommended steps or approaches (worksheets?) for preparing for a divorce mediation meeting? Should the mediator get any background information about the situation, or can/should the mediator function with no knowledge of the specifics of the charges and counter\-charges? If background information is in order, who provides it. What is the role of the Guadian ad Litem (GAL) in a mediation meeting? Does the GAL take an active role on behalf of the offspring or just reply to inquiries.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Usually and ideally, a GAL would take an active role in parenting questions, while taking a secondary role in property division and maintenance with the primary concern being that the economic arrangements are sustainable and don't subject the child to hardship when with the other parent (e.g. many divorcing parents fail to realize that maintaining two households will result in more child related expenses than one).

I will assume that you are asking from the perspective of a party to the divorce and not from the perspective of a mediator, although the phrasing is not entirely clear. Some basics:

1. Have a good command of the facts about your finances, your ex's finances, and the children's schedules and needs (assuming that there are children).
