38.answer:
Here's a difficult multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: John lives in a rural area of Utah and encounters a mountain lion on his property. The animal is 50 feet away from his house and appears to be stalking his dog, which is tied up outside. Under what circumstances would John be legally justified in shooting the mountain lion?

A) John can shoot the mountain lion immediately to protect his property and pet.
B) John can shoot the mountain lion only if it comes within 10 feet of his house.
C) John can shoot the mountain lion if he reasonably believes it's about to attack his dog and he has no safe way to retreat or protect the dog otherwise.
D) John cannot shoot the mountain lion under any circumstances without first obtaining a hunting license.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: According to the Utah rule cited in the passage, a person is legally justified in killing a threatening wild animal when they reasonably believe such action is necessary to protect themselves, another person, or a domestic animal against an imminent attack that will likely result in severe injury or death. The rule also states that factors such as the nature and immediacy of the danger, the probability of attack, and the ability to safely retreat should be considered. 

Option A is incorrect because mere presence on property or potential threat to property alone does not justify killing the animal. 

Option B is arbitrary and not supported by the law. 

Option D is incorrect because self-defense against wild animals does not require a hunting license. 

Option C is correct because it aligns with the legal justification outlined in the Utah rule, considering the imminent threat to the domestic animal (dog) and the inability to safely retreat or otherwise protect it.

documentation.title: difference between 'assigned' and 'endorsed' in this context?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: 
> Each such notice of redemption shall be irrevocable and shall specify
>  the date that is the redemption date, the redemption price, the number
>  of Shares to be redeemed, the place or places of payment and that
>  payment will be made upon presentation and, to the extent that such
>  Shares are certificated, surrender of the certificate(s) evidencing
>  the Shares of Series B Preferred Stock to be redeemed (properly
>  ***endorsed*** or ***assigned*** for transfer, if the Corporation shall so
>  require).

I know the basic meanings of both words. However, as a non\-native speaker, I fear there might be some specialized nuance here that I can't seem to grasp.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: "Endorsement" in this case refers to the concept of negotiation. If a negotiable document with one owner (such as a check or promissory note or negotiable bond or stock certificate) is signed (i.e. "endorsed") in the proper place on the original document by that owner, then the person who is in physical possession of the endorsed document (the "holder" of the endorsed document) is now its true owner. There is a body of statutory and case law setting forth which documents may and may not be negotiated in this manner (in the United States, this is located mostly in the Uniform Commercial Code). 

If the endorsement is made on a separate piece of paper attached to the negotiable document it is called an "[allonge](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Allonge)", and it could fairly be called either an endorsement or an assignment.

An "assignment" would be a transfer of ownership concluded in some manner other than negotiation of the original document by endorsing it, for example, by a bill of sale document signed by the owner declaring that the new owner is the person who is now presenting the stock.

39.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: In the context of redeeming shares of Series B Preferred Stock, which of the following best describes the difference between "endorsed" and "assigned" stock certificates?

A) Endorsed certificates are signed on the back, while assigned certificates are transferred via a separate document.

B) Endorsed certificates can only be transferred to financial institutions, while assigned certificates can be transferred to any party.

C) Endorsed certificates require a notary's seal, while assigned certificates do not.

D) Endorsed certificates are always more valuable than assigned certificates.

Correct Answer: A

Explanation: The key difference between "endorsed" and "assigned" stock certificates lies in the method of transfer. An endorsed certificate is typically signed directly on the original document, usually on the back, which allows for negotiation and transfer of ownership to the holder of the endorsed document. This is a form of negotiation governed by specific laws, such as the Uniform Commercial Code in the United States.

On the other hand, an assigned certificate involves transferring ownership through a separate document, such as a bill of sale, rather than by endorsing the original certificate itself. This method of transfer is called an assignment.

Option B is incorrect because the ability to transfer to different parties is not the distinguishing factor between endorsed and assigned certificates. Option C is false because notarization is not a defining characteristic of either method. Option D is incorrect as the value of the stock is not determined by whether it's endorsed or assigned.

documentation.title: Statutes of limitations and the pre-action protocol (PAP)
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: Suppose A has a claim against B and the statute of limitations stipulates that it must be brought to the court within 2 years.

Suppose 23,7 months elapse so there is still time (precisely 0,3 months \-\- less than two weeks) to bring the claim to the court, however, the court expects one to have first gone through the PAP which often allows the respondent 2 weeks to reply to the claimant's first letter.

The claimant no longer has time to send a PAP\-Letter Before Claim, but they are still within the statutorily allowed timeframe to bring the claim before the court.

What is the claimant expected to do in this situation? Give the respondent a shortened allowance of time in which to respond to their letter that would still expire within the time limit for the claimant to go to court lest they fail to come to a solution between themselves? File the claim with the court before the deadline to do so while still waiting for the respondent to have their full customary 14 days and the eat the cost of the court filing fee if it proves to be unnecessary due to successful amicable settlement of the matter through the pre\-action protocol whilst awaiting the court to list the cause in its calendar? Or something altogether different from both of these options?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: [united\-states](/questions/tagged/united-states "show questions tagged 'united-states'")

In the US, a statute of limitations has been complied with if the cases is initially **filed** within the limitation period. The tiem needed for any pre\-trial activities, including discovery, motions to suppress evidence, motions to dismiss, and the like, is not part of the limitation period.

In civil cases the court can waive the limit for "good cause". In criminal cases, there is usually no waiver unless the defendant consents.

I had thought that the rules would be similar in E\&W, but I am not at all sure of that.

40.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: In a civil case where the statute of limitations is approaching, what is the most appropriate action for a claimant to take if they have not yet completed the Pre-Action Protocol (PAP) but are still within the statutorily allowed timeframe to bring the claim before the court?

A) Send a PAP Letter Before Claim with a shortened response time for the respondent
B) File the claim with the court before the deadline, while simultaneously proceeding with the PAP
C) Request an extension of the statute of limitations from the court
D) Abandon the claim if the full PAP cannot be completed within the limitation period

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: Option B is the most appropriate action in this scenario. By filing the claim with the court before the statute of limitations expires, the claimant preserves their right to pursue the case. This action complies with the limitation period, as the case is considered "brought" when it is filed with the court. Simultaneously proceeding with the Pre-Action Protocol demonstrates good faith and adherence to court expectations, even if it's not completed before filing. This approach balances legal compliance with procedural expectations.

Option A risks non-compliance with the PAP and could be seen as unreasonable. Option C is incorrect because in most jurisdictions, courts cannot extend statutes of limitations in civil cases (though there may be exceptions). Option D is unnecessarily drastic and forfeits the claimant's rights when legal options are still available.

documentation.title: Where can I find a comprehensive document of computer laws?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: I am interested in computers and want to pursue this interest further by getting my education in programming and security. I've only just started so I'm scared that I might break some law that was not obvious to me and get into some trouble. It is not my intention to break the law like so many juvenile computer hackers intend on doing for kicks, or what have you.

The question is, where can I find the laws on computer/internet use for the U.S.A.?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Ensuring that you are compliant with all laws is a notorious problem. For example, [nobody has successfully enumerated even the *number* of criminal laws under the U.S. (federal) code](http://blogs.loc.gov/law/2013/03/frequent-reference-question-how-many-federal-laws-are-there/)!

There's a book that delves into this problem called [3 Felonies a Day](http://www.threefeloniesaday.com/Youtoo/tabid/86/Default.aspx). The title alludes to the (unverifiable) suggestion that a typical person unwittingly commits three felonies a day. (There is some discussion of that claim [on Skeptics.SE](https://skeptics.stackexchange.com/q/22530/26652) ... and regular amusement published at <https://twitter.com/CrimeADay.>)

In practice, you can look for safe harbors. [Obtaining and following the advice of a licensed lawyer](https://law.stackexchange.com/a/51953/10) [offers some indemnification](https://law.stackexchange.com/questions/8032/why-do-non-lawyers-refer-you-to-lawyers-even-when-they-know-the-answer/8037#comment15411_8037). For example, if you are part of an institution you can vet your planned activities with its ethics and/or legal counsel. If those activities are later found to have violated a law then that approval could *conceivably* (but not certainly) transfer liability to the institution.

41.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given documentation:

Question: According to the information provided, which of the following statements best represents the challenge of ensuring compliance with all laws in the United States, particularly in the context of computer and internet use?

A) It is a straightforward process to enumerate all criminal laws under the U.S. federal code.
B) The average person commits exactly three felonies a day without realizing it.
C) It is virtually impossible to know with certainty that one is complying with all applicable laws at all times.
D) Following the advice of any individual, regardless of their credentials, provides complete legal protection.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: 
Option A is incorrect because the documentation explicitly states that nobody has successfully enumerated even the number of criminal laws under the U.S. federal code.

Option B is incorrect. While the concept of "three felonies a day" is mentioned, it's described as an unverifiable suggestion, not a proven fact.

Option C is correct. The documentation highlights the difficulty in ensuring compliance with all laws, mentioning that even counting the number of federal criminal laws is problematic. This implies that it's virtually impossible for an individual to be certain they're complying with all applicable laws at all times.

Option D is incorrect. While the documentation mentions that obtaining and following the advice of a licensed lawyer offers some indemnification, it doesn't guarantee complete legal protection. The text states that approval from institutional legal counsel could "conceivably (but not certainly) transfer liability."

documentation.title: Javascript license
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: I am just entering the field of web development and I was wondering if the Javascript language has a license for the development of web applications for commercial purposes or there is a fee to pay for its use (for commercial purposes). I have been looking for information but I am not sure if it is in charge of Mozilla or Ecmascript, I have even read that "Javascript" is a registered trademark of Oracle, but in either case I cannot find anything regarding the license. Could you help me by indicating if the use of this language to develop web applications commercially is free or if you know the license, please indicate it to me?

Daniel

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: [Here](https://www.gnu.org/philosophy/javascript-trap.html) is a good discussion, below citing from this text:

> The JavaScript language itself, as a format, is free, and use of JavaScript in a web site is not necessarily bad. However, as we've seen above, it can be bad—if the JavaScript program is nonfree.

You can use it for commercial web applications, but you have to be careful with libraries which might come with all kind of licenses.

Furthermore from [Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/JavaScript#Trademark):

> "JavaScript" is a trademark of Oracle Corporation in the United States. It is used under license for technology invented and implemented by Netscape Communications and other parties.

That's why you might run into trouble if you use the name, see e.g. [here](https://law.stackexchange.com/questions/56712/what-to-do-if-you-are-sued-for-company-name-that-resemble-an-existing-company-na).

42.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding the commercial use of JavaScript for web development?

A) JavaScript requires a paid license from Oracle for any commercial use.
B) The JavaScript language itself is free to use, but developers must be cautious about the licenses of libraries they incorporate.
C) Mozilla owns all rights to JavaScript and charges a fee for commercial web applications.
D) ECMAScript, not JavaScript, is the only version that can be used freely for commercial purposes.

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: The JavaScript language itself is free to use, even for commercial purposes. However, developers need to be careful about the licenses of any JavaScript libraries or frameworks they incorporate into their projects, as these may come with different licensing terms. While Oracle owns the trademark for "JavaScript," this doesn't affect the use of the language itself. The key is to understand that the core language is free, but additional components may have specific licensing requirements.

documentation.title: What are the legal bounds of a "well regulated militia"?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: Let's say a team of well equipped, former special forces soliders left the U.S. Army and formed a "militia." Legally, what could some of their missions be, if they were even allowed to operate? Who would authorize that, if anyone? What are the legal bounds of this organization/militia? 

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: There are no laws restricting a number of people forming a group and calling themselves a militia or similar sounding military name. The factors that limit the activities of any militia or similar group are the same that oversee all of us: state and federal laws.

To begin with, any such militia or group may run afoul of laws if they are perceived to be attempting to confuse the public and state/federal governments of their legitimacy and actual command. And, of course, the federal government will not allow an ad\-hoc militia group to subvert their own authority. 

A self\-organized militia of ex\-military types could self\-assign "missions" of any nature, as long as they did not break applicable state and federal laws for firearms, applicable laws that require permits for assembly and parades in public spaces, laws regarding threats and intimidation while in public, and laws regarding [Sedition (Wikipedia)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sedition), among others.

These "missions" could be patrolling cities and reporting crimes and helping old ladies cross the street, like an armed version of the [Guardian Angels (Wikipedia)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guardian_Angels). But more aligned with current events, some possible examples are the [Oath Keepers (Wikipedia)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oath_Keepers): they gather at request (or by their own mission directive) and "provide security" (their description) for other groups \- during public rallies and demonstrations \- that have (typically right wing) political views aligned with their own. They appear in military garb and are heavily armed, but are allowed to assemble and "operate" (their term), as long as they are within the bounds of state and federal laws. (There are instances of laws being "bent" by law enforcement to allow militias to "operate" i.e. [Occupation of the Malheur National Wildlife Refuge (Wikipedia)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Occupation_of_the_Malheur_National_Wildlife_Refuge); but typically, federal authorities supersede). But a militia could also claim to be non\-partisan, or even left wing, such as the [Redneck Revolt (Wikipedia)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Redneck_Revolt).

Such militias organize and authorize their own "missions", much like any group, like the Boy Scouts. The only outside authorizations they may need are legal permits, where required, for their activities, such as assembling and parading in public, among others. If a militia is run as a [501(c) organization (Wikipedia)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/501(c)_organization) they are also bound by those financial and governing laws.

The *legal* bounds of how a militia operates in public (and in some cases, within private spheres) are \- like anyone else \- the applicable state and federal laws: for firearms (open carry, concealed carry, long guns, automatic weapons, etc.), laws regarding threats and intimidation (since they are usually armed and their modus operandi is intimidation) and assault, as well as any laws regarding assembly and parades, and sedition.

43.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: A group of former U.S. Army special forces soldiers forms a militia. Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding the legal bounds and operations of this militia?

A) The militia can operate freely without any legal restrictions as long as they don't impersonate official military personnel.

B) The militia's operations are entirely governed by federal law, with no influence from state laws.

C) The militia can conduct any missions they choose, as long as they obtain authorization from local law enforcement.

D) The militia's activities are limited by both state and federal laws, including those related to firearms, public assembly, and sedition.

Correct Answer: D

Explanation: The correct answer is D. According to the documentation, militias are subject to the same state and federal laws that govern all citizens. These include laws related to firearms, public assembly, threats and intimidation, and sedition. The militia cannot operate freely without restrictions (ruling out option A), nor are they governed solely by federal law (ruling out option B). They do not need specific authorization from local law enforcement for all their activities (ruling out option C), but rather must comply with existing laws and obtain necessary permits for certain public activities. The militia can self-assign "missions," but these must remain within the bounds of applicable state and federal laws.

documentation.title: Are lethal autonomous weapon systems legal?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: Are lethal autonomous weapon systems legal?

I want to know whether this technology is illegal, or not \- specifically in the UK, but globally as well.

I know the Convention on Certain Conventional Weapons held a conference in December, regarding the legalities of this technology, but did not hear of anything being determined. I also think the US has some military law regarding "meaningful human control."

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: While your question is primarily directed towards the use of legal autonomous weapons systems by military forces, I will address one tangential point (I may provide a separate answer on the military issues later).

There is a long standing (i.e. many hundreds of years old) common law rule of premises liability in Britain, which has now been incorporated by law into a statute and is also the law in almost every other common law jurisdiction, that creates liability to a person injured by a private parties using lethal autonomous weapons systems (i.e. deadly traps).

44.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given information:

Question: According to long-standing common law in Britain, which has been incorporated into statute, what is the legal status of using lethal autonomous weapon systems (such as deadly traps) on private property?

A) It is fully legal as long as warning signs are posted.
B) It creates liability for the property owner if someone is injured.
C) It is only legal if used by military personnel.
D) It is permitted if the system is registered with local authorities.

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: The passage states that there is a "long standing (i.e. many hundreds of years old) common law rule of premises liability in Britain, which has now been incorporated by law into a statute" that "creates liability to a person injured by a private parties using lethal autonomous weapons systems (i.e. deadly traps)." This directly supports answer B, indicating that using such systems on private property would create liability for the owner if someone is injured. The other options are not supported by the given information and introduce elements not mentioned in the passage.

documentation.title: Department of Motor Vehicles driving test makes no sense!
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: I have just received an instructional permit in the state of California after passing my written test at the Department of Motor Vehicles. I am currently trying to find opportunities to use this instructional permit for the very purpose it was issued to me, namely to practice driving with an individual holding a valid driver's license before the real deal.

At the DMV, I was advised to find a "friend" who could allow me to use their car to practice and then bring this "friend" as well as their vehicle to the DMV. The DMV does not provide vehicles on test day. I have two major problems with this:

1\) "Bring a friend" is not very professional or rigorous legal jargon. What if none of my friends have cars? What if I have no friends? 

2\) It so happens that some of my friends do have cars. However they all have the same legitimate reaction when I ask for help.There reaction is unanimously "What about insurance?" Their name is on the insurance, so if something happens to the car during our practice or even during the driving test at the DMV, they are ultimately responsible. Is the challenge of finding someone who is willing to jump in head first to a possible legal entanglement part of the driving test?

Someone please help as this makes no legal sense to me. 

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: As far as I know in the United States, no DMV provides test vehicles. 

You need a vehicle to take the driving test.

Since you are *not* currently licensed, you *can not* legally drive yourself to the test alone... 

So logically, you *must* bring someone... anyone... willing to drive you to the test and provide a vehicle for you to test in. As others have stated in the comments above, worse case scenario is the hiring of a driving instructor.

If you read the written instructions (and I remember correctly), it does state something along the lines of "must be accompanied by a licensed driver and provide an insured, registered, vehicle". Which is a bit more formal than the "bring a friend". Most people just naturally use more casual terms when speaking. I don't know your age, but it's probably more common to hear "bring a parent" than "bring a friend" when *speaking* face to face with the DMV staff. 

Also, not all insurance policies are driver limited. Some policies are on the vehicle regardless of driver. **Typically Liability\-only insurance is vehicle specific, not driver specific**. [\[\*1]](http://www.claimsjournal.com/news/national/2014/06/05/249762.htm) You'd have to review the policies or call the insurance agents to confirm this. 

You may even do something as simple as add you to the current insurance for a month or two while you're practicing and testing. Just reimburse your friend for any increase in premiums during this time. Contact the insurance company/agent. The cost may be minimal. 

In addition, there are **[non\-owner insurance policies](http://www.insure.com/car-insurance/non-owners-policy.html)** which cover you even if you do not own a vehicle. This would provide insurance if none of your friends has a policy which would work.

Realize that *most* people taking the test for the first time have probably already been added to a policy owned by their parents. So, your situation is a bit more unique. It's not meant to be inherently confusing but if you're "outside the norm" you have to do some deductive reasoning on your own.

And finally, if an accident or damage were to happen during *your* practicing or testing, it would *still be your responsibility*. **If you are in control of the vehicle, you are responsible for any damage to it or damage caused by the vehicle due to any negligence on your part, regardless of any insurance policy.** You'd be a pretty bad "friend" if you caused damage and didn't financially make restitution leaving your "friend" holding the bag, so to speak. Restitution could be something as simple as paying the deductible on your friend's policy. Of course, if you are *not* covered by insurance any claim may be denied \-\- leaving *you* responsible for everything. The mindset that just because your friend owns the car they are totally responsible for anything that happens while ***your*** driving seem very, very self\-serving and, well, I'd be apprehensive about loaning you my vehicle as well. In fact, I absolutely would *not*.

45.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given documentation:

Question: According to the information provided, which of the following statements is most accurate regarding insurance coverage for a learner driver practicing in someone else's car?

A) The car owner's insurance will always cover any driver using the vehicle, regardless of the policy type.

B) Liability-only insurance policies are typically specific to the driver, not the vehicle.

C) Non-owner insurance policies can provide coverage for individuals who don't own a vehicle but need to drive occasionally.

D) The learner driver is never financially responsible for damages they cause while practicing, as long as the car is insured.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The correct answer is C. The documentation mentions that non-owner insurance policies exist to cover individuals who do not own a vehicle but need to drive occasionally, which would apply to a learner driver practicing in someone else's car.

Option A is incorrect because not all insurance policies cover any driver using the vehicle; some are driver-specific.

Option B is incorrect. The documentation actually states that typically, liability-only insurance is vehicle-specific, not driver-specific.

Option D is incorrect. The information clearly states that if the learner driver is in control of the vehicle, they are responsible for any damage caused by their negligence, regardless of the insurance policy in place.

Option C is the most accurate statement based on the provided information, as it correctly identifies a potential solution for insurance coverage for learner drivers who don't own their own vehicles.

documentation.title: What does "materially different" mean?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: My father is an artist who is considering building a sculpture for an organization. as part of the contract he is prohibited from making copies of the sculpture in the future, or any works that are not "materially different".

> Nothing in this Agreement shall, however, prevent the Artist from making other works of art that are materially different than the Artwork using combinations of the same materials and in different configuration".

What does "materially different" mean in this case? How different do future sculptures need to be to qualify?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: 
> What does "materially different" mean in this case? How different do future sculptures need to be to qualify?

There really is no precise set of standards or strict criterion, but the issue has to do with likelihood of confusion.

A subsequent sculpture created by your father would qualify as "materially different" unless it renders a reasonable person unable to distinguish between that and the organization's one without making a rather detailed comparison.

46.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given information:

Question: An artist signs a contract to create a unique sculpture for an organization. The contract prohibits the artist from making copies or similar works in the future, unless they are "materially different." Which of the following scenarios would most likely be considered a violation of this contract clause?

A) The artist creates a new sculpture using the same materials but in a completely different shape and size.

B) The artist creates a miniature version of the original sculpture as a personal keepsake.

C) The artist creates a painting that depicts the sculpture in abstract form.

D) The artist creates a sculpture with a similar theme but using entirely different materials and techniques.

Correct Answer: B

Explanation:
A) This scenario likely qualifies as "materially different" because the shape and size are completely different, even if the materials are the same.

B) This is the correct answer because a miniature version of the original sculpture would be very similar and could cause confusion, thus violating the "materially different" clause.

C) A painting, even if it depicts the sculpture, would likely be considered materially different due to the change in medium and artistic interpretation.

D) Using different materials and techniques while only maintaining a similar theme would likely result in a work that is distinct enough to be considered "materially different."

The key factor in determining if a work is "materially different" is whether a reasonable person could easily distinguish it from the original without detailed comparison. A miniature version would be too similar and could potentially cause confusion, making it the most likely scenario to violate the contract.

documentation.title: How can a person legally create a site to download an app and profit from the site?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: Does a site operator need a permission from the app owner by a contract or something like that to run a site where people pay for and download apps? If this is true how can someone get such permission? Does it cost money?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Assuming that the question is how one creates a site on which to sell apps created by others to the general public, this depends on how the app has been released.

Apps are pretty much always creative works, and as such are protected by copyright. The initial owner of the copyright is the developer, or in some cases the developer's employer. However the copyright may be sold, given, assigned, left, or otherwise transferred to another.

The copyright owner has the exclusive right to make, or authorize the making of, copies of the protected work. The copyright owner also has the exclusive right to distribute the work to the public, or authorize its distribution. In US law these are protected by [17 USC 106](https://www.copyright.gov/title17/92chap1.html#106). In other countries such rights are protected by the various local copyright laws. These rights are also guaranteed by the [Berne Copyright Convention](https://wipolex.wipo.int/en/text/283698) Specifically, Article 9, paragraph 1 of the convention reads:

> (1\) Authors of literary and artistic works protected by this Convention shall have the exclusive right of authorizing the reproduction of these works, in any manner or form.

A website that allows the public to download apps, whether for a fee or for free, involves both making copies of the apps, and distributing them to the public. As such it requires permission from the copyright owner. In the absence of such permission, the site operator is engaging in copyright infringement.

Some apps have been released by their owners under permissive licenses which allow others to copy and distribute them for a fee. A site could legitimately host any app whose copyright owner has so released it.

In the absence of such a permissive release, the distributor must obtain permission. There is no standard method of doing this. One must find some way to communicate with the owner, or some authorized agent of the owner, and ask. If one cannot find the owner, or the owner does not respond, this must be treated as a refusal, and the app may not be distributed. Some owners list contact info in their apps or the documentation.

The copyright owner may demand a fee for such permission. This could be a fixed advance fee, or a per\-copy or percentage fee royalty, or both, or some other fee structure. The owner may also require some specific form of attribution, or make other conditions. Any such conditions must be complied with. It is usual for the owner's agreement to be incorporated into a binding contract, but this is not strictly required.

Distribution without permission is copyright infringement, unless an ***exception to copyright*** applies. In the case described above, providing a site for retail purchase of apps written by various others, it is hard to see how any exception would apply. The US concept of ***fair use*** pretty clearly would not apply.

The owner may bring suit against an infringer. If the owner wins such a suit, the owner may be awarded monetary damages, and a court order against further infringement. In some cases the owner may also be able to collect legal fees and other costs of suit from the infringer. The exact rules for damages vary by country, and the details will vary with the particular case. In the US, under [17 USC 504](https://www.copyright.gov/title17/92chap5.html#504) the owner may elect to get statutory damages (which can be up to $150,000 per work infringed for willful infringement) or actual damages, which include both losses to the owner, and any profits made by the infringer.

In some cases copyright infringement may also be a crime, and can be prosecuted by the government. In the US, [17 USC 506](https://www.copyright.gov/title17/92chap5.html#506) makes infringement a crime when the infringement is:

* "purposes of commercial advantage or private financial gain", and
* of copies with the retail value of over $1,000 during a period of 6 months.

However, my understanding is that actual prosecution by the US Justice Department is unusual unless infringement is carried out on a major commercial basis, well over the statutory threshold.

47.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: A website operator wants to create a platform where users can purchase and download mobile applications. Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding the legal requirements for such an operation?

A) The website operator can freely distribute any mobile application as long as they charge a fee for it.

B) Permission is only required from app developers if the website plans to offer the apps for free.

C) The website operator must obtain permission from the copyright owner of each app before making it available for download, unless the app is released under a permissive license.

D) Copyright laws do not apply to mobile applications, so no permissions are necessary.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The correct answer is C. According to copyright law, apps are protected creative works. The copyright owner has the exclusive right to make copies and distribute the work to the public. A website that allows users to download apps, whether for a fee or for free, involves both copying and distributing, which requires permission from the copyright owner. The only exception would be if the app has been released under a permissive license that explicitly allows such distribution.

Option A is incorrect because charging a fee does not negate the need for permission. Option B is false because permission is required regardless of whether the app is offered for free or for a fee. Option D is incorrect because copyright laws do indeed apply to mobile applications, just as they do to other forms of software and creative works.

documentation.title: Can the original author of a WTFPL Project be sued for patent infringement?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: So I browsed through the [WTFPL Feedback Section](http://www.wtfpl.net/feedback/) and found this question unanswered (actually [it was answered](http://www.wtfpl.net/feedback/#comment-1205) but I do not want to gun down people in the streets).
[![enter image description here](https://i.stack.imgur.com/Ljw23.png)](https://i.stack.imgur.com/Ljw23.png)

So, if somebody sues you, can they actually win the process?
If so, how would I have to modify the license so there are no legal consequences for me when licensing my project?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: ### No

Patent laws vary between countries, but a general feature is that one can only patent *their own original inventions*. If somebody else knew the details of the invention before the patent was applied for ([prior art](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prior_art)), the patent is not valid.

So if somebody else tried to get a patent on your invention, you (or anyone else) could simply provide the patent office with evidence of prior art. This would be particularly easy to do if you had already released the invention to the public, since potentially anyone could testify that they knew about the invention. Their application would then be rejected.

If they were awarded the patent without anybody noticing, and then tried to sue you (or some third party) for infringement, you could likewise produce the prior art, and their patent would be declared invalid and their lawsuit dismissed.

48.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: A software developer releases a project under the WTFPL (Do What The F*** You Want To Public License). Later, another individual attempts to patent the core algorithm of this project. Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding the legal implications?

A) The patent will be automatically granted, and the original developer will be liable for infringement.

B) The patent office will reject the application outright due to the use of the WTFPL license.

C) If the patent is mistakenly granted, the original developer can have it invalidated by providing evidence of prior art.

D) The WTFPL license protects the developer from all legal consequences, including patent disputes.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The correct answer is C. If someone attempts to patent an invention that has already been publicly disclosed, such as through an open-source software release, this constitutes prior art. Even if a patent is mistakenly granted, the original developer (or any other party) can challenge the patent's validity by providing evidence of prior art. This would likely result in the patent being invalidated and any related lawsuits being dismissed.

Option A is incorrect because the patent should not be automatically granted if prior art exists. Option B is incorrect because the license type itself doesn't directly influence the patent office's decision; it's the public disclosure that matters. Option D is incorrect because while the WTFPL is a very permissive license, it doesn't provide specific protection against patent disputes; that protection comes from the concept of prior art in patent law.

documentation.title: Are interrogation tapes of suspects in a closed case publicly available?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: Do people have a right to demand tapes from interrogations/witness questioning done in relation to a closed case?

I read somewhere that the tapes are only publicly available if they have been used as evidence in court. Not sure if this is true though.

I'm interested in the NYC jurisdiction.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: This depends on what “publicly available” means. As far as I know, no jurisdiction actively disseminates investigation material, such as recorded interviews with suspects, to the public in the same way that the authorities publish laws and judicial decisions.

When evidence of a police interview is adduced in open court, it becomes “public” in the sense that the information can generally be published (for example, by a journalist sitting in the courtroom). This freedom can overcome confidentiality obligations that may have applied to the information before it was admitted in evidence.

But court records are not “public” in the sense that they can be easily found on a freely accessible database. The courts still control access to the record and use this control to charge fees and limit the record’s dissemination in the interests of justice. It is uncommon for courts to grant non\-party or media access to sensitive exhibits (eg. where widespread publication would unreasonably harm a witness or party’s privacy), even if this information was “published” to those physically present in the courtroom which was open to the public.

Many jurisdictions have detailed legislation governing access to court documents, as well as legally enforceable disclosure requests using subpoenae or freedom of information laws. To receive a more precise answer, you need to specify the jurisdiction and your reason for requesting the document.

49.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: In New York City, which of the following statements is most accurate regarding public access to interrogation tapes from closed cases?

A) All interrogation tapes are automatically made public once a case is closed.
B) Interrogation tapes are only publicly available if they have been used as evidence in court, but access may still be restricted.
C) The public has an unrestricted right to demand and receive any interrogation tapes from closed cases.
D) Interrogation tapes are never made available to the public under any circumstances.

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: The correct answer is B. According to the information provided, interrogation tapes that have been used as evidence in court become "public" in the sense that the information can generally be published. However, this doesn't mean unrestricted access. Courts still control access to these records and may limit dissemination in the interests of justice or to protect privacy. Access may be granted through specific legal procedures like subpoenas or freedom of information requests, but it's not automatic or unrestricted. 

Option A is incorrect because not all tapes are automatically made public when a case closes. Option C is false because there isn't an unrestricted right to demand and receive these tapes. Option D is too extreme, as tapes can become available under certain circumstances, particularly if used as evidence in court.

documentation.title: Overriding offered contract acceptance methods with express written declaration
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: Bob would rather face the consequences of trespassing than pay for a license to occupy a privately owned parking spot.

He pulls into the lot which says “by parking here you agree to pay £10/hour.

Bob wishes to reject this offer to buy a license and so park his car without any license, ie as a trespasser.

He makes this clear by displaying a sign in his windshield or by donning a bumper sticker that reads “I AM TRESPASSING,” or perhaps simply “TRESPASSER”.

Has Bob accepted or rejected the proprietor’s contract?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: ### The offeror has stipulated that acceptance is to be by conduct

As explained in [another answer](https://law.stackexchange.com/a/92400/46948), given that the offeror has stipulated that parking in the lot will constitute acceptance, and given that the offeror is master of the offer, then the question is whether the act of parking in the lot constitutes acceptance of the contract. I outlined the test in that other answer and will only summarize here: the question becomes "[whether the offeror, acting reasonably, would understand that the offeree was assenting to the terms proposed](https://ca.vlex.com/vid/communication-of-acceptance-683505725)." This is acceptance by conduct. This is [an *objective* inquiry](https://law.stackexchange.com/questions/90788/does-contract-formation-require-subjective-meeting-of-the-minds) focusing on how the actions would be understood to a reasonable observer, not an inquiry into the actual states of mind of the offeror or offeree.

An example of the above law being applied can be found in [*University of Edinburgh v. Onifade*, 2005 S.L.T. (Sh. Ct.) 63](https://www.scotcourts.gov.uk/search-judgments/judgment?id=b39287a6-8980-69d2-b500-ff0000d74aa7):

> The pursuers' notice made it plain that their position was that anyone who parked on their property without a permit would have to pay them a fee of £30 per day on that account. The defender, by parking his vehicle on their property without a permit, made it plain that he accepted that position. He signified his acceptance by his conduct in so doing. It is nothing to the purpose for him to maintain that he did not intend to pay because he considered that the pursuers were not entitled to make the charge specified. 'The judicial task is not to discover the actual intentions of each party; it is to decide what each was reasonably entitled to conclude from the attitude of the other.'

See also [*Imperial Parking Canada Corporation v. Toronto (City)*, 2007 ONCA 649](https://www.canlii.org/en/on/onca/doc/2007/2007onca649/2007onca649.html). The signs said:

> Impark is by this sign offering space for public parking. You accept this offer by parking on this lot. Do not park on this lot if you do not agree to these terms and conditions … If you park and do not display a valid ticket or pass the rate is $69\.55 per day or portion thereof.

The judge found:

> the signs posted on Impark’s lots expressly state that Impark consents to the parking of cars without payment in advance and held that the fees that Impark collects are sums owing to it in contract rather than damages for trespass

In another parking lot example, [*Imperial Parking Ltd. v. Canada*, 2000 CanLII 15612 (FCA)](https://www.canlii.org/en/ca/fca/doc/2000/2000canlii15612/2000canlii15612.html), the Federal Court of Appeal said:

> In my view, the unequivocal conduct which constitutes acceptance of the appellant's offer to provide a parking space occurs when the driver leaves the lot after parking his or her vehicle. This interpretation is reinforced by the text of the large sign posed at the entrance to the appellant's lot. That is the point in time in which an owner can be deemed to have accepted the appellant's offer. **Any time before that moment, a driver can demonstrate his rejection of the appellant's offer by driving away.** Those who purchase a ticket must be deemed to have accepted the appellant"s contractual terms upon leaving their parked vehicle in the appellant's lot. **As for those who park their vehicles but fail to pay, the act of non\-payment is more consistent with the intention to breach a contract than a refusal to enter into one.**

### Bob's sign/note/sticker is not likely an effective rejection of the offer

I understand you to be asking whether Bob's sign constitutes rejection of the offer such that Bob's subsequent conduct no longer would be considered acceptance of the contract.

A rejection would terminate the offer, such that it can no longer be accepted. However, *rejection must be communicated to the offeror* (*Chitty on Contracts*, § 4\-124\). In examples where apparent acceptance by conduct is negated by evidence of contrary intention, the offeror was in a position to be aware of the rejector's manifest expression of that contrary intention (see examples in *Chitty on Contracts*, § 4\-035\).

50.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: Bob parks his car in a private lot with signs stating "by parking here you agree to pay £10/hour." He places a large sign in his windshield that says "I DO NOT ACCEPT YOUR OFFER AND AM TRESPASSING." The lot owner was not present when Bob parked and did not see the sign. What is the most likely legal outcome?

A) Bob has successfully rejected the offer and is trespassing, not bound by the contract.
B) Bob has accepted the contract by his conduct of parking, regardless of his sign.
C) The contract is void due to a lack of meeting of the minds.
D) Bob's sign creates an entirely new contract overriding the lot owner's terms.

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: Based on the legal principles outlined in the documentation, Bob's act of parking in the lot would likely be considered acceptance by conduct, regardless of his subjective intent or the sign in his windshield. The courts apply an objective test, focusing on how a reasonable person would interpret the actions, not the parties' actual states of mind. 

The lot owner stipulated that parking constitutes acceptance, and as the "master of the offer," their terms for acceptance generally prevail. Bob's sign is unlikely to be an effective rejection because it was not communicated to the offeror (lot owner). The act of parking and leaving the vehicle in the lot is more consistent with accepting and then breaching the contract rather than rejecting it outright.

Cases like University of Edinburgh v. Onifade support that parking in such circumstances constitutes acceptance even if the parker did not intend to pay. The Imperial Parking cases further reinforce that leaving a vehicle parked is the key act of acceptance, and non-payment is seen as a breach rather than a rejection of the contract.

documentation.title: Lost merchandise: Replacement or refund
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: Bob ordered something on eBay from a seller and wins the auction for £40\. The item is in good condition but more usually goes for closer to £150\. Perhaps it has some uncommon quality that especially suits Bob but not others thus making it more expensive (like a phone locked to what is incidentally his favoured network) or perhaps it just happened to go for less by a fluke of luck but in any case Bob spent a fair bit of effort monitoring the market for the product he wanted at a favourable price.

He orders it and the seller posts it to an eBay product collection point, and Bob gets notified that it has been received thereby and thus is ready for him to collect.

Bob goes to the pickup location which is inside a partner business like an Argos but they say they cannot find it anywhere given the collection code or Bob’s name as an addressee.

This is apparently Argos’s failure but they say to speak to eBay. Bob clicks the item not arrived button on eBay which caused consternation for the seller who immediately posts their proof of posting in defense.

Firstly should Argos or eBay be the subject of the question?

And secondly, surely Bob would be entitled to a refund, presumably from eBay or possibly Argos, and one would hope not the seller, but does that really compensate Bob? When is another bargain like that for the item he wanted going to come along again? Most products are more expensive or they are locked to a different network or they are designed for right handed individuals etc so none really suit him and rarely for the price of £40\.

Who is liable and are they liable for a replacement or a refund?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: [canada](/questions/tagged/canada "show questions tagged 'canada'")

### Common\-law remedy: expectation damages

The general measure of damages for breach of contract is *expectation damages*: "the plaintiff will be entitled to the value of the promised performance" (*Bank of America Canada v. Mutual Trust Co.*, [2002 SCC 43 at paragraph 26](https://canlii.ca/t/51s8#par26)); "the purpose of expectation damages is to put the plaintiff in the same position it would have been *if the contract had been performed* (*Grandeur Homes Inc. v. Zeng*, [2021 ONSC 4005 at paragraph 19](https://canlii.ca/t/jgdx0#par19)). Unless Bob's contract specifies some other entitlement in the case of non\-delivery, Bob will likely be awarded expectation damages.

As a starting point, courts are likely to view the market value of the contract (e.g. £40\) as the floor for expectation damages, but it is open to Bob to prove higher expectation damages by demonstrating the cost of obtaining a sufficiently similar alternative, while reasonably attempting to mitigate damages. That is: Bob should not simply announce a million\-pound open bid for a similar phone, and Bob should not wait around if the price is increasing, but Bob could enter another reasonably competitive auction. Also, if Bob can prove losses incurred by not having the item in the meantime, those will also form part of the expectation damages.

### Statute: Sales of Goods Acts essentially provide for expectation damages

Provincial Sale of Goods Acts also say this. See e.g. [Ontario's](https://www.ontario.ca/laws/statute/90s01):

> The measure of damages is the estimated loss directly and naturally resulting in the ordinary course of events from the seller’s breach of contract.
> 
> 
> Where there is an available market for the goods in question, the measure of damages is, in the absence of evidence to the contrary, to be ascertained by the difference between the contract price and the market or current price of the goods at the time or times when they ought to have been delivered, or, if no time was fixed, then at the time of the refusal to deliver.

51.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given information:

Question: Bob wins an eBay auction for a phone at £40, which normally sells for £150. The item is not delivered due to an error at the pickup location. Which of the following best describes Bob's likely entitlement under common law principles of contract damages?

A) Bob is only entitled to a refund of the £40 he paid, as that was the agreed contract price.

B) Bob is entitled to £150, as that is the typical market value of the phone.

C) Bob is entitled to the cost of obtaining a sufficiently similar phone through reasonable efforts, which may exceed £40 but is not automatically £150.

D) Bob has no entitlement, as the failure was due to a third party (Argos) rather than the seller.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The correct answer is C. Under the principle of expectation damages, Bob would be entitled to be put in the same position as if the contract had been performed. This doesn't automatically mean the typical market price (£150), but it also isn't limited to just the contract price (£40). Bob would be entitled to the cost of obtaining a sufficiently similar phone through reasonable efforts to mitigate his damages. This could exceed £40 if Bob can't find a similar deal, but he's also expected to make reasonable efforts to find a good price, not simply pay the full market price without trying to find a better deal. Additionally, Bob might be able to claim for any provable losses incurred by not having the phone in the meantime.

documentation.title: What counts as a medical facility?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: A certain POA for medical document gives an adult son the right to move his parent to medical facility. Would a assisted living place count as a medical facility?

Is there a precise legal definition of a medical facility?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: This is a logical thing to ask but somewhat misses the point as described below, because a POA doesn't really give the adult son "**the right** to move his parent to medical facility" in the ordinary sense of that word.

> Is there a precise legal definition of a medical facility?

Not usually, in the context of interpreting a power of attorney, unless the document itself defines it.

> Would a assisted living place count as a medical facility?

This could go either way but often it doesn't matter much because it is mitigated by the next point, and because there is usually also a non\-medical durable power of attorney put in place at the same time that would give the agent or a different agent the authority to take steps necessary to move the principal (the parent in this case) to a non\-medical facility like a new apartment or home.

> A certain POA for medical document gives an adult son the right to
> move his parent to medical facility.

This somewhat overstates what a POA does. A POA gives an agent under the POA (the adult son in this case) the authority to take action to make something happen. But a POA does not give the agent the authority for make the parent do anything if the principal (the parent in this case) is conscious and capable of expressing a contrary opinion and a POA also does not give the agent the power to prohibit the principal from doing anything.

Only a guardian of the person who is suffering from some condition has the authority to act over the objections of that person. Action with a POA requires the non\-objection of the principal because the principal is silent or incapable of communicating any objections.

Normally, someone well enough to be placed in an assisted living facility has enough capacity to object to the placement and override the agent if that person is unhappy with a decision that the agent is making under the POA. This can be done on a case by case basis, or by revoking the POA entirely.

52.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: A son has been given medical power of attorney (POA) for his elderly father. The son believes his father needs to be moved to an assisted living facility for better care. Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding the son's authority in this situation?

A) The son has the absolute right to move his father to an assisted living facility, regardless of his father's wishes.

B) The son can only move his father to a medical facility, and an assisted living facility does not qualify as such.

C) The son has the authority to initiate the move, but cannot force his father to go if the father is capable of expressing objection.

D) The son needs to obtain guardianship before he can make any decisions about moving his father.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The correct answer is C. A medical POA gives the agent (in this case, the son) the authority to make healthcare decisions and take actions on behalf of the principal (the father). However, it does not give the agent the right to override the principal's wishes if the principal is conscious and capable of expressing their own desires. The son can initiate the process of moving his father to an assisted living facility, but if the father objects and is mentally competent to do so, the son cannot force the move. 

Option A is incorrect because a POA does not grant absolute rights over the principal's choices. 

Option B is incorrect because the definition of a "medical facility" in a POA context is often not strictly defined, and an assisted living facility could potentially be considered appropriate under a medical POA.

Option D is incorrect because guardianship is a separate legal process and is not automatically required just because there is disagreement; the POA is still valid unless revoked or challenged.

documentation.title: Stealing through multiple people
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: Person b steals a car from person a by forging the registration ie a civil manner.

Then person c steals the car.

How would a civil lawsuit work? Would person a sue b and c at the same time? Or sue them separately? 

Is the transfer from b to c conveyance even though b didn't consent?

Person b now has no assets so suing them alone is useless.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: I'm not sure there would be any need \- or any ability to bring \- any civil action.

Forgery would appear to count as a Category D felony under [Section 205\.090](https://casetext.com/statute/nevada-revised-statutes/title-15-crimes-and-punishments/chapter-205-crimes-against-property/forgery-counterfeiting-and-issuance-of-check-or-draft-with-intent-to-defraud/section-205090-forgery-of-conveyances-negotiable-instruments-stock-certificates-wills-and-other-instruments-utterance-of-forged-instrument) and, "In addition to any other penalty, the court shall order the person to pay restitution.", so person "a"'s damages should have been met under the process of the criminal prosecution of person "b" for forgery, with nothing further to claim.

Person "c" will have stolen a car. Whether that car was legitimately owned by person "a" may only be relevant if person "c" is using their belief that it belonged to person "b" as mitigation (for example recovery of a debt \- though it won't help much as this should have been done through proper channels), which again would be a criminal proceeding.

53.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given information:

Question: In a complex car theft scenario involving three parties (A, B, and C), where B steals A's car through forgery and C subsequently steals the car from B, what is the most appropriate legal course of action for A to recover damages?

A) A should file separate civil lawsuits against B and C for theft and damages.
B) A should file a joint civil lawsuit against both B and C for conspiracy to commit theft.
C) A should rely on the criminal prosecution of B for forgery, which includes restitution, and the separate criminal prosecution of C for theft.
D) A should file a civil lawsuit against C only, as B has no assets to recover.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The most appropriate course of action is C because:

1. The forgery committed by B is likely to be treated as a Category D felony, which includes a provision for restitution to the victim (A) as part of the criminal prosecution.
2. The subsequent theft by C would be handled as a separate criminal matter, regardless of the car's ownership status at the time of the theft.
3. Civil lawsuits may be unnecessary or ineffective in this case, as the criminal proceedings should address the damages and restitution.
4. Pursuing separate or joint civil lawsuits could be more complex and potentially less effective than relying on the criminal justice system to handle both offenses and provide restitution.

documentation.title: How much detail does one include in a complaint?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: I literally spent the entire day working on my complaint, but just read (on avvo) that providing too much detail can get the suit dismissed. My complaint recounts each detail of the situation in order to refute the libelous claims, but would it be more appropriate to just state the claim of libel without the backstory?

It's not a block of text; it's a list of facts, following the sample complaint form, but should I skip the details (which, again, refute the libelous claims) and start with the person libeling me?

Sorry for all the questions. I'm worried about my case being dismissed for not being in the right format or not following procedure etc.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: 
> How much detail does one include in a complaint?

See the procedural law your jurisdiction and how courts apply it. You only mention that [you suing in the US](https://law.stackexchange.com/questions/67338/how-much-detail-does-one-include-in-a-complaint/67343#comment141658_67338), but not the state or even whether your complaint is to be filed in federal or state court. The applicable "*court rules*" or "*rules of civil procedure*" of your jurisdiction provide guidance on how much detail pleadings are expected to include.

Also make sure you read case law such as [*Ashcroft v. Iqbal*, 129 S.Ct. 1937, 1949 (2009\)](https://www.leagle.com/decision/insco20090518941) and the cases cited therein. For instance, "*the pleading standard \[...] does not require detailed factual allegations, but it demands more than an unadorned, the\-defendant\-unlawfully\-harmed\-me accusation \[...] A pleading that offers "labels and conclusions" or "a formulaic recitation of the elements of a cause of action will not do. \[...] Nor does a complaint suffice if it tenders naked assertion\[s] devoid of "further factual enhancement*" (citations and internal quotation marks omitted).

It is usually difficult for litigant with no prior experience and no background in law to discern what is relevant or even what are the prima facie elements (or defenses) that ought to be established. That is why doing legal research prior to filing one's pleadings is strongly encouraged. Unfortunately many pro se litigants (including me) are unaware of the importance of doing *enough* preparatory work when we file our first complaint.

> but just read (on avvo) that providing too much detail can get the suit dismissed.

That in and of itself is not a sound statement. Did that person elaborate or provide any sources for that assertion? Typically there is some amount of litigation before a court dismisses a case. During that litigation the plaintiff has the opportunity to amend the complaint or posit how the pleadings are clear enough for ascertaining the merits of a claim.

54.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given documentation:

Question: According to the information provided, which of the following statements is most accurate regarding the level of detail required in a legal complaint?

A) Complaints should always include extensive details to refute all potential counterarguments.
B) Providing too much detail will automatically result in a case being dismissed.
C) The appropriate level of detail depends on the specific jurisdiction's procedural laws and relevant case law.
D) Complaints should only contain a brief statement of the claim without any supporting facts.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The correct answer is C. The documentation emphasizes that the appropriate level of detail in a complaint depends on the specific jurisdiction's procedural laws and how courts apply them. It also mentions the importance of considering relevant case law, such as Ashcroft v. Iqbal, which provides guidance on pleading standards. The answer highlights that while detailed factual allegations are not always required, the complaint must provide more than just a bare accusation or a formulaic recitation of the elements of a cause of action. Options A and B are too extreme and not supported by the given information, while D contradicts the guidance provided in the documentation about including sufficient factual enhancement.

documentation.title: Is it true that electrically assisted pedal cycles must be limited to 6mph if operating with twist throttles?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: What provision or instrument requires this, if so?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: This isn't true. In order to not be treated as a motor vehicle, "twist and goes" must be capable of pedal operation and must not provide electrical assistance above 15\.5 mph.

[https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/electrically\-assisted\-pedal\-cycles\-eapcs/electrically\-assisted\-pedal\-cycles\-eapcs\-in\-great\-britain\-information\-sheet](https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/electrically-assisted-pedal-cycles-eapcs/electrically-assisted-pedal-cycles-eapcs-in-great-britain-information-sheet)

55.answer:
Here's a difficult multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: Under UK law, which of the following statements is correct regarding the classification of "twist and go" electric bicycles?

A) All "twist and go" electric bicycles are automatically classified as motor vehicles, regardless of their specifications.

B) "Twist and go" electric bicycles are not classified as motor vehicles if they can be operated by pedals and have a maximum electrically assisted speed of 20 mph.

C) "Twist and go" electric bicycles are exempt from motor vehicle classification if they have a maximum power output of 250 watts, regardless of their top speed.

D) To avoid being classified as motor vehicles, "twist and go" electric bicycles must be capable of pedal operation and must not provide electrical assistance above 15.5 mph.

Correct Answer: D

Explanation: According to the UK government's information on Electrically Assisted Pedal Cycles (EAPCs), "twist and go" electric bicycles are not automatically classified as motor vehicles. To be exempt from motor vehicle classification, they must meet specific criteria. The correct answer, D, accurately states these criteria: the bicycle must be capable of pedal operation and must not provide electrical assistance above 15.5 mph (25 km/h). 

Option A is incorrect because it overgeneralizes, stating that all "twist and go" bicycles are classified as motor vehicles, which is not true if they meet the specified criteria.

Option B is incorrect because it states the wrong speed limit. The correct maximum speed for electrical assistance is 15.5 mph, not 20 mph.

Option C is incorrect because while power output is a factor in EAPC regulations (limited to 250W), it is not the sole determining factor for motor vehicle classification exemption. The speed limit and pedal operation capability are crucial components.

This question tests the examinee's understanding of the specific legal requirements for electric bicycle classification in the UK, requiring careful attention to detail and the ability to distinguish between similar but incorrect statements.

documentation.title: Is it ok to use slack in EU without data residency option?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: Since you can only setup Slack data residency in EU on the most expensive plans, is it ok to use their service still under GDPR rules without that option?
Would signing a DPA stating they are compliant would be enough?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: When you are the data controller, and are transferring data under your control into non\-European countries, you need to protect that transfer. Slack proposes that you use the “standard contractual clauses” (SCCs) mechanism, which is incorporated into their DPA. To enter into SCCs, you as the controller must be convinced that the data importer on the other end is also able to enter into these SCCs. This cannot be the case if the data importer is subject to non\-European laws that could require disclosure without legal basis.

In the Schrems II judgement, the partial adequacy decision for the United States was invalidated. SCCs can still be a valid transfer tool. However, exactly the same reasons that invalidated the adequacy decision also call into question whether US\-based companies can enter into SCCs: electronic communications services can be compelled to disclose personal data to US intelligence agencies without suitable options for redress by the data subjects. Slack is such an US\-based company that is probably within scope of these spy laws.

If no sufficient legal protections are available, SCCs might still be permissible by implementing supplemental measures that effectively prevent access to the personal data by US intelligence agencies, such as end to end encryption with keys that never leave Europe. The EDPB has issued [recommendations on such measures](https://edpb.europa.eu/our-work-tools/our-documents/recommendations/recommendations-012020-measures-supplement-transfer_en). However, such technical measures are generally incompatible with SaaS services such as Slack.

Thus, you must perform an analysis of the available legal and technical measures:

* If you find that Slack is subject to relevant US laws and that you cannot implement supplemental measures, then the data transfer is probably illegal.
* Otherwise, a transfer based on SCCs combined with suitable supplemental measures might be legal.

In this answer, “Europe” means the UK for the UK GDPR, and EU/EEA for the EU GDPR.

56.answer:
Here's a difficult multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: A European company is considering using Slack for internal communication but is concerned about GDPR compliance. Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding the use of Slack under GDPR rules?

A) Signing a Data Processing Agreement (DPA) with Slack is sufficient to ensure GDPR compliance, regardless of data residency.

B) Using Slack is always GDPR-compliant as long as the company pays for the most expensive plan with EU data residency.

C) The company must perform a thorough analysis of available legal and technical measures, including the possibility of implementing supplementary measures like end-to-end encryption, before determining if using Slack is GDPR-compliant.

D) Slack can never be GDPR-compliant for European companies due to US surveillance laws, regardless of any measures taken.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The correct answer is C because it accurately reflects the complexity of the situation. According to the documentation, simply signing a DPA or choosing an expensive plan with EU data residency is not enough to ensure GDPR compliance. The company must conduct a detailed analysis of the legal and technical measures available, including the potential implementation of supplementary measures like end-to-end encryption. This analysis should consider whether Slack is subject to relevant US laws that could compel data disclosure and whether effective supplementary measures can be implemented. Only after this thorough assessment can the company determine if using Slack is GDPR-compliant. Options A and B oversimplify the compliance process, while option D is too absolute and doesn't account for the possibility of implementing effective supplementary measures that could potentially make Slack use compliant.

documentation.title: Child Labor in Entertainment
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: Why is the entertainment industry exempt from the [Fair Labor Standards Act](https://www.dol.gov/whd/flsa/)?
I have no idea how to research this question.
edit: I mean, I thought the constitution specifies that laws shall be equally enforced.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: There is a specific exemption in [29 USC 213(c)(3\)](https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/29/213) that

> The provisions of section 212 of this title relating to child labor
>  shall not apply to any child employed as an actor or performer in
>  motion pictures or theatrical productions, or in radio or television
>  productions.

See [this article](https://www.law.upenn.edu/journals/jbl/articles/volume6/issue2/Krieg6U.Pa.J.Lab.&Emp.L.429%282004%29.pdf) for further analysis, a propos state laws. Incidentally, the act defines "[oppressive child labor](https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/29/203)" as:

> a condition of employment under which (1\) any employee under the age
>  of sixteen years is employed by an employer (other than a parent or a
>  person standing in place of a parent employing his own child or a
>  child in his custody under the age of sixteen years in an occupation
>  other than manufacturing or mining or an occupation found by the
>  Secretary of Labor to be particularly hazardous for the employment of
>  children between the ages of sixteen and eighteen years or detrimental
>  to their health or well\-being) in any occupation, or (2\) any employee
>  between the ages of sixteen and eighteen years is employed by an
>  employer in any occupation which the Secretary of Labor shall find and
>  by order declare to be particularly hazardous for the employment of
>  children between such ages or detrimental to their health or
>  well\-being; but oppressive child labor shall not be deemed to exist by
>  virtue of the employment in any occupation of any person with respect
>  to whom the employer shall have on file an unexpired certificate
>  issued and held pursuant to regulations of the Secretary of Labor
>  certifying that such person is above the oppressive child\-labor age.
>  The Secretary of Labor shall provide by regulation or by order that
>  the employment of employees between the ages of fourteen and sixteen
>  years in occupations other than manufacturing and mining shall not be
>  deemed to constitute oppressive child labor if and to the extent that
>  the Secretary of Labor determines that such employment is confined to
>  periods which will not interfere with their schooling and to
>  conditions which will not interfere with their health and well\-being.

Without the statutory exemption, if you are under 16 and employed by a non\-parent, in any occupation, that is oppressive child labor. But because of the specific exemption, what would otherwise be statutorily oppressive child labor is allowed.

The political "why" question (why did the bill contain such language) is extremely difficult to answer. The only substantive clues that I have seen are in a [1959 dissertation](https://etd.ohiolink.edu/!etd.send_file?accession=osu1486475308017293&disposition=inline) by G.E. Paulsen and [this article](https://scholarship.law.duke.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1972&context=lcp) on the passage of the act. It seems to be a legislative compromise relating stricter original standards, and was particularly driven by the need to allow children to work on family farms. The relevant clause was added from the floor of the House on May 24, 1938 by Rep Charles Kramer (CA). This is recorded on p. 7441 of the Congressional Record, which, unfortunately, is not freely available online. The two toughest questions were asked by Schneider (WI), Kramer's reply in parentheses:

> The gentleman's amendment would exempt children engaged only 
>  in the making of moving pictures? (The gentleman is correct) 
>  There are very few young people employed in that occupation?
>  (Very few. There are hardly more than 10 employed at one 
>  time.)

Shirley Temple *was* in fact invoked by Kramer.

57.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: Which of the following statements best explains the exemption of child actors from the Fair Labor Standards Act's child labor provisions?

A) The Constitution mandates equal enforcement of all labor laws, but the entertainment industry successfully lobbied for an exception.
